And lay your hands again upon my sword.
Swear by my sword
Never to speak of this that you have heard.
paragraphs.translated: You're everywhere, aren't you? Maybe we should move. Come over here, gentlemen, and put your hands on my sword again. Swear by my sword you'll never mention what you've heard.

paragraphs.original:
(beneath) Swear by his sword.
(beneath)
paragraphs.translated:
(from under the stage) Swear by his sword.
(from under the stage)

paragraphs.original:
Well said, old mole! Canst work i' th' earth so fast?
A worthy pioneer! Once more remove, good friends.
paragraphs.translated: You said it right, old mole. You're pretty busy down there in the dirt, aren't you? What a tunneler! Let's move again, my friends.

paragraphs.original: O day and night, but this is wondrous strange!
paragraphs.translated: My God, this is unbelievably strange.

paragraphs.original:
And therefore as a stranger give it welcome.
There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio,
Than are dreamt of in your philosophy. But come,
Here, as before, never, so help you mercy,
How strange or odd soe'er I bear myself
(As I perchance hereafter shall think meet
To put an antic disposition on),
That you, at such times seeing me, never shall - 
With arms encumbered thus, or this headshake,
Or by pronouncing of some doubtful phrase,
As "Well, well, we know," or "We could an if we would,"
Or "If we list to speak," or "There be an if they might,"
Or such ambiguous giving out - to note
That you know aught of me. This not to do,
So grace and mercy at your most need help you,
Swear.
paragraphs.translated: Then give it a nice welcome, as you would give to any stranger. There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than you've even dreamed of. But now listen to me. No matter how strangely I act (since I may find it appropriate to act a little crazy in the near future), you must never, ever let on - with a gesture of your hands or a certain expression on your face - that you know anything about what happened to me here tonight. You must never say anything like, "Ah, yes, just as we suspected," or "We could tell you a thing or two about him," or anything like that. Swear you won't.

paragraphs.original:
(beneath) Swear!
(beneath)
paragraphs.translated:
(from under the stage) Swear.
(from under the stage)

paragraphs.original:
Rest, rest, perturbèd spirit! - So, gentlemen,
With all my love I do commend me to you,
And what so poor a man as Hamlet is
May do, to express his love and friending to you,
God willing, shall not lack. Let us go in together,
And still your fingers on your lips, I pray.
The time is out of joint. O cursèd spite,
That ever I was born to set it right!
Nay, come, let's go together.
paragraphs.translated:
Okay, then, unhappy ghost, you can rest now. So, gentlemen, I thank you heartily and with all my love, and I'll repay you however I can some day. Let's go back to court together, but shhh, please. No talking about this. There is so much out of whack in these times. And damn the fact that I'm supposed to fix it! Come on, let's go.
shhh

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS with his man REYNALDO
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS enters with his servant REYNALDO.

paragraphs.original: Give him this money and these notes, Reynaldo.
paragraphs.translated: Give him this money and these letters, Reynaldo.

paragraphs.original: I will, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I will, sir.

paragraphs.original:
You shall do marvelous wisely, good Reynaldo,
Before you visit him, to make inquire
Of his behavior.
paragraphs.translated: It would be wonderfully wise of you, my dear Reynaldo, to ask around about his behavior a little before you visit him.

paragraphs.original: My lord, I did intend it.
paragraphs.translated: That's what I thought too, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, well said, very well said. Look you, sir,
Inquire me first what Danskers are in Paris,
And how, and who, what means, and where they keep
What company at what expense; and finding
By this encompassment and drift of question
That they do know my son, come you more nearer
Than your particular demands will touch it.
Take you, as 'twere, some distant knowledge of him,
As thus: "I know his father and his friends,
And, in part, him." Do you mark this, Reynaldo?
paragraphs.translated: Excellent, very good. Ask around and find out what Danish people are in Paris - who they are, where they live and how much money they have, who their friends are. And if you find out in this general sort of questioning that they happen to know my son, you'll find out much more than if you asked specific questions about him. Just tell them you vaguely know Laertes, say something like, "I'm a friend of his father and I sort of know him," or whatever. Do you get what I'm saying, Reynaldo?

paragraphs.original: Ay, very well, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, very well, sir.

paragraphs.original:
"And in part him, but," you may say, "not well.
But, if 't be he I mean, he's very wild.
Addicted so and so. - " And there put on him
What forgeries you please. Marry, none so rank
As may dishonor him. Take heed of that.
But, sir, such wanton, wild, and usual slips
paragraphs.translated: You should say, "I sort of know him, but not well. Is it the same Laertes who's a wild party animal? Isn't he the one who's always," and so on. Then just make up whatever you want - of course, nothing so bad that it would shame him. I mean make up any stories that

paragraphs.original:
As are companions noted and most known
To youth and liberty.
paragraphs.translated: sound like your average young guy, the kind of trouble they get into.

paragraphs.original: As gaming, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Like gambling, sir?

paragraphs.original:
Ay, or drinking, fencing, swearing,
Quarreling, drabbing - you may go so far.
paragraphs.translated: That's right, or drinking, swearing, fist-fighting, visiting prostitutes - that kind of thing.

paragraphs.original: My lord, that would dishonor him!
paragraphs.translated: But that would ruin his reputation!

paragraphs.original:
'Faith, no, as you may season it in the charge.
You must not put another scandal on him
That he is open to incontinency.
That's not my meaning. But breathe his faults so quaintly
That they may seem the taints of liberty,
The flash and outbreak of a fiery mind,
A savageness in unreclaimèd blood,
Of general assault.
paragraphs.translated: Oh no, not if you say it right. I don't want you to say he's a sex fiend, that's not what I mean. Just mention his faults lightly, so they make him seem like a free spirit who's gone a little too far.

paragraphs.original: But, my good lord -
paragraphs.translated: But, sir -

paragraphs.original: Wherefore should you do this?
paragraphs.translated: Why should you do this, you want to know?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord. I would know that.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir. I'd like to know.

paragraphs.original:
Marry, sir, here's my drift:
(And I believe it is a fetch of wit)
You, laying these slight sullies on my son
As 'twere a thing a little soiled i' th' working - 
Mark you, your party in converse, him you would sound,
Having ever seen in the prenominate crimes
The youth you breathe of guilty, be assured
He closes with you in this consequence:
"Good sir" or so, or "Friend," or "Gentleman,"
According to the phrase or the addition
Of man and country.
paragraphs.translated: Well, here's what I'm thinking. (I'm quite proud of myself for coming up with this.) As you talk with someone and hint about my son's faults and little sins, you'll watch his reaction, and if he's ever seen Laertes do any of these things, it will only be natural for him to agree with you, at which point he'll call you "sir," or "my good friend," depending on who the person is, where he comes from, and so on.

paragraphs.original: Very good, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir.

paragraphs.original: And then, sir, does he this, he does -  What was I about to say? By the mass, I was about to say something. Where did I leave?
paragraphs.translated: And then he'll … he'll … wait, what was I about to say? Good God, I was about to say something. What was I saying?

paragraphs.original:
At "closes in the consequence," at "‘friend,'
Or so" and "‘gentleman.'"
paragraphs.translated: At, "It will be natural for him to agree with you … he'll call you ‘sir,' ‘friend,'" et cetera.

paragraphs.original:
At "closes in the consequence." Ay, marry.
He closes thus: "I know the gentleman.
I saw him yesterday" - or "t' other day,"
Or then, or then, with such or such - "and, as you say,
There was he gaming, there o'ertook in's rouse,
There falling out at tennis," or, perchance,
"I saw him enter such a house of sale" - 
Videlicet a brothel, or so forth. See you now,
Videlicet
Your bait of falsehood takes this carp of truth.
And thus do we of wisdom and of reach,
With windlasses and with assays of bias,
By indirections find directions out.
So by my former lecture and advice
Shall you my son. You have me, have you not?
paragraphs.translated: "It will be natural for him to agree with you." Ah, yes, that's right. If he agrees he'll say something like this: "Yes, I know the gentleman you're referring to. I just saw him yesterday," or "the other day," or whenever it is, you know, "and there he was gambling," or "there he was, totally wasted, or fighting with somebody about a tennis match, or going into a house of ill repute" - that means a whorehouse, you know - or whatever. Make sure your little lie brings out the truth. We're doing this wisely and intelligently, indirectly, finding out things by roundabout means. That's how you'll find out what my son is up to in Paris. You get my point, don't you?

paragraphs.original: My lord, I have.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I do, sir.

paragraphs.original: God be wi' you. Fare you well.
paragraphs.translated: God bless you. Have a safe trip.

paragraphs.original: Good my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, sir.

paragraphs.original: Observe his inclination in yourself.
paragraphs.translated: Don't forget to see what he's up to with your own eyes. Don't trust gossip.

paragraphs.original: I shall, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I will, sir.

paragraphs.original: And let him ply his music.
paragraphs.translated: And I hope he's studying his music like he's supposed to.

paragraphs.original: Well, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Got it, sir.

paragraphs.original: Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye.

paragraphs.original: Exit REYNALDO
paragraphs.translated: REYNALDO exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter OPHELIA
paragraphs.translated: OPHELIA enters.

paragraphs.original: How now, Ophelia? What's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: Ophelia, what's the matter?

paragraphs.original: O my lord, my lord, I have been so affrighted!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, father, father, I've just had such a scare!

paragraphs.original: With what, i' th' name of God?
paragraphs.translated: From what, in God's name?

Father, I was up in my room sewing when Hamlet came in with no hat on his head, his shirt unbuttoned, and his stockings dirty, undone, and down around his ankles. He was pale as his undershirt, and his knees were knocking together. He looked so out of sorts, as if he'd just come back from hell. He came up to me.

paragraphs.original: Mad for thy love?
paragraphs.translated: Is he crazy with love for you?

paragraphs.original:
My lord, I do not know.
But truly, I do fear it.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not sure, but I'm afraid he might be.

paragraphs.original: What said he?
paragraphs.translated: What did he say?

paragraphs.original:
He took me by the wrist and held me hard.
Then goes he to the length of all his arm,
And, with his other hand thus o'er his brow,
He falls to such perusal of my face
As he would draw it. Long stayed he so.
paragraphs.translated: He grabbed me by the wrist and held me hard, then backed away an arm's length and just looked at me, staring at me like an artist about to paint my picture. He stayed like that a long time.

paragraphs.original:
At last, a little shaking of mine arm
And thrice his head thus waving up and down,
He raised a sigh so piteous and profound
As it did seem to shatter all his bulk
And end his being. That done, he lets me go,
And, with his head over his shoulder turned,
He seemed to find his way without his eyes,
For out o' doors he went without their helps,
And to the last bended their light on me.
paragraphs.translated: Finally, after shaking my arm a little, and jerking his head up and down three times, he sighed like it was his last breath. After that he let me go. He left the room with his head turned back on me, finding his way out without looking, since his eyes were on me the whole time.

paragraphs.original:
Come, go with me. I will go seek the king.
This is the very ecstasy of love,
Whose violent property fordoes itself
And leads the will to desperate undertakings
As oft as any passion under heaven
That does afflict our natures. I am sorry.
What, have you given him any hard words of late?
paragraphs.translated: Come with me. I'll go tell the king about this. This is definitely love-craziness. Love is such a violent emotion that it makes people self-destruct, as much as any strong emotion. I'm so sorry. Did you tell him anything that might have hurt his feelings lately?

paragraphs.original:
No, my good lord. But as you did command
I did repel his fetters and denied
His access to me.
paragraphs.translated: No, father, but I did what you told me to do and sent back his letters and wouldn't let him visit me.

paragraphs.original:
That hath made him mad.
I am sorry that with better heed and judgment
I had not quoted him. I feared he did but trifle
And meant to wreck thee. But beshrew my jealousy!
By heaven, it is as proper to our age
To cast beyond ourselves in our opinions
As it is common for the younger sort
To lack discretion. Come, go we to the king.
This must be known, which, being kept close, might move
More grief to hide than hate to utter love.
Come.
paragraphs.translated: That's what made him crazy. I regret not observing him more closely before I told you to do that. I thought he was just toying with you and meant to ruin your reputation. Damn my suspicious thoughts! It's as common for us old people to assume we know more than we do as for young people to be too wild and crazy. Come on, let's go see the king. We've got to discuss this matter, which could cause more trouble if we keep it secret than if we discuss it openly.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Flourish. Enter King CLAUDIUS and Queen GERTRUDE, ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN, and attendants
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. CLAUDIUS and GERTRUDE enter with ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and attendants.

paragraphs.original:
Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern.
Moreover that we much did long to see you,
The need we have to use you did provoke
Our hasty sending. Something have you heard
Of Hamlet's "transformation" - so call it
Since nor th' exterior nor the inward man
Resembles that it was. What it should be,
More than his father's death, that thus hath put him
So much from th' understanding of himself,
I cannot dream of. I entreat you both
That, being of so young days brought up with him
And since so neighbored to his youth and 'havior,
That you vouchsafe your rest here in our court
Some little time so by your companies
To draw him on to pleasures and to gather,
So much as from occasion you may glean,
Whether aught, to us unknown, afflicts him thus
That, opened, lies within our remedy.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome, dear Rosencrantz and Guildenstern. I've wanted to see you for a long time now, but I sent for you so hastily because I need your help right away. You've probably heard about the "change" that's come over Hamlet - that's the only word for it, since inside and out he's different from what he was before. I can't imagine what's made him so unlike himself, other than his father's death. Since you both grew up with him and are so familiar with his personality and behavior, I'm asking you to stay a while at court and spend some time with him. See if you can get Hamlet to have some fun, and find out if there's anything in particular that's bothering him, so we can set about trying to fix it.

paragraphs.original:
Good gentlemen, he hath much talked of you.
And sure I am two men there are not living
To whom he more adheres. If it will please you
To show us so much gentry and good will
As to expend your time with us awhile
For the supply and profit of our hope,
Your visitation shall receive such thanks
As fits a king's remembrance.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, Hamlet's talked a lot about you, and I know there are no two men alive he's fonder of. If you'll be so good as to spend some time with us and help us out, you'll be thanked on a royal scale.

paragraphs.original:
Both your majesties
Might, by the sovereign power you have of us,
Put your dread pleasures more into command
Than to entreaty.
paragraphs.translated: Both you and the king might have ordered us to execute your command, instead of asking us so politely.

paragraphs.original:
But we both obey
And here give up ourselves, in the full bent,
To lay our service freely at your feet
To be commanded.
paragraphs.translated: But we'll obey. Our services are entirely at your command.

paragraphs.original: Thanks, Rosencrantz and gentle Guildenstern.
paragraphs.translated: Thanks, Rosencrantz and worthy Guildenstern.

paragraphs.original:
Thanks, Guildenstern and gentle Rosencrantz.
And I beseech you instantly to visit
My too much changèd son. Go, some of you,
And bring these gentlemen where Hamlet is.
paragraphs.translated:
Thanks, Guildenstern and worthy Rosencrantz.
I beg you to pay a visit right away to my son, who's changed too much. Servants, take these gentlemen to see Hamlet.

paragraphs.original:
Heavens make our presence and our practices
Pleasant and helpful to him!
paragraphs.translated: I hope to God we can make him happy and do him some good!

paragraphs.original: Ay, amen!
paragraphs.translated: Amen to that!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN, escorted by attendants
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit, escorted by attendants.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
Th' ambassadors from Norway, my good lord,
Are joyfully returned.
paragraphs.translated: The ambassadors are back from Norway, sir.

paragraphs.original: Thou still hast been the father of good news.
paragraphs.translated: Once again you bring good news.

paragraphs.original:
Have I, my lord? I assure my good liege,
I hold my duty as I hold my soul,
Both to my God and to my gracious king.
paragraphs.translated: Do I, sir? I assure your majesty I'm only doing my duty both to my God and my good king.

paragraphs.original:
And I do think - or else this brain of mine
Hunts not the trail of policy so sure
As it hath used to do - that I have found
The very cause of Hamlet's lunacy.
paragraphs.translated: And I believe - unless this brain of mine is not so politically cunning as it used to be - that I've found out why Hamlet's gone crazy.

paragraphs.original: Oh, speak of that. That do I long to hear.
paragraphs.translated: Tell me! I want very much to find out.

paragraphs.original:
Give first admittance to th' ambassadors.
My news shall be the fruit to that great feast.
paragraphs.translated: All right, but first let the ambassadors speak. Then you can hear my news, as dessert.

paragraphs.original: Thyself do grace to them, and bring them in.
paragraphs.translated: Then be so kind as to show them in.

paragraphs.original: Exit POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
He tells me, my dear Gertrude, he hath found
The head and source of all your son's distemper.
paragraphs.translated: Gertrude, he says he's found out the reason for your son's insanity.

paragraphs.original:
I doubt it is no other but the main:
His father's death and our o'erhasty marriage.
paragraphs.translated: I doubt it's anything but the obvious reason: his father's dying and our quick marriage.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS with ambassadors VOLTEMAND and CORNELIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS enters with the ambassadors VOLTEMAND and CORNELIUS.

paragraphs.original:
Well, we shall sift him. - Welcome, my good friends!
Say, Voltemand, what from our brother Norway?
paragraphs.translated: Well, we'll get to the bottom of it. Welcome, my good friends. Tell me, Voltemand, what's the news from the king of Norway?

paragraphs.original:
Most fair return of greetings and desires.
Upon our first, he sent out to suppress
His nephew's levies, which to him appeared
To be a preparation 'gainst the Polack,
But, better looked into, he truly found
It was against your highness. Whereat grieved - 
That so his sickness, age, and impotence
Was falsely borne in hand - sends out arrests
On Fortinbras, which he, in brief, obeys,
Receives rebuke from Norway, and in fine
Makes vow before his uncle never more
To give th' assay of arms against your majesty.

Whereon old Norway, overcome with joy,
paragraphs.translated: Greetings to you too, your Highness. As soon as we raised the matter, the king sent out messengers to stop his nephew's war preparations, which he originally thought were directed against Poland but learned on closer examination were directed against you. He was very upset that Fortinbras had taken advantage of his being old and sick to deceive him, and he ordered Fortinbras's arrest. Fortinbras swore never to threaten Denmark again.

paragraphs.original:
Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee
And his commission to employ those soldiers,
So levied as before, against the Polack,
With an entreaty, herein further shown,
That it might please you to give quiet pass
Through your dominions for this enterprise,
On such regards of safety and allowance
As therein are set down. (gives CLAUDIUS a document
(gives
a document
paragraphs.translated:
The old king was so overjoyed by this promise that he gave young Fortinbras an annual income of three thousand
crowns and permission to lead his soldiers into Poland, asking you officially in this letter to allow his troops to pass through your kingdom on their way to Poland. He's assuring you of your safety. (he gives CLAUDIUS a document
crowns



(he gives
a document

paragraphs.original:
It likes us well,
And at our more considered time we'll read,
Answer, and think upon this business.
Meantime we thank you for your well-took labor.
Go to your rest. At night we'll feast together.
Most welcome home!
paragraphs.translated: I like this news, and when I have time I'll read this and think about how to reply. Meanwhile, thank you for your efforts. Go relax now. Tonight we'll have dinner. Welcome back!

paragraphs.original: Exeunt VOLTEMAND and CORNELIUS
paragraphs.translated: VOLTEMAND and CORNELIUS exit.

paragraphs.original:
This business is well ended.
My liege and madam, to expostulate
What majesty should be, what duty is,
Why day is day, night night, and time is time,
Were nothing but to waste night, day, and time.
Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit
And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,
I will be brief: your noble son is mad.
Mad call I it, for, to define true madness,
What is 't but to be nothing else but mad?
But let that go.
paragraphs.translated: Well, that turned out well in the end. Sir and madam, to make grand speeches about what majesty is, what service is, or why day is day, night is night, and time is time is just a waste of a lot of day, night, and time. Therefore, since the essence of wisdom is not talking too much, I'll get right to the point here. Your son is crazy. "Crazy" I'm calling it, since how can you say what craziness is except to say that it's craziness? But that's another story.

paragraphs.original: More matter, with less art.
paragraphs.translated: Please, stick to the point.

paragraphs.original:
Madam, I swear I use no art at all.
That he is mad, 'tis true. Tis true, 'tis pity,
And pity 'tis 'tis true - a foolish figure,
But farewell it, for I will use no art.
Mad let us grant him then. And now remains
paragraphs.translated: Madam, I'm doing nothing but sticking to the point. It's true he's crazy, and it's a shame it's true, and it's truly a shame he's crazy - but now I sound foolish, so I'll get right to the point.

paragraphs.original:
That we find out the cause of this effect,
Or rather say, the cause of this defect,
For this effect defective comes by cause.
Thus it remains, and the remainder thus. Perpend.
I have a daughter - have while she is mine - 
Who in her duty and obedience, mark,
Hath given me this. Now gather and surmise.
(reads a letter) "To the celestial and my soul's idol, the most beautified Ophelia" - That's an ill phrase, a vile phrase. "Beautified" is a vile phrase. But you shall hear. Thus: (reads the letter)"In her excellent white bosom, these," etc. - 
(reads a letter)
 - 
(reads the letter)
paragraphs.translated:
Now, if we agree Hamlet's crazy, then the next step is to figure out the cause of this effect of craziness, or I suppose I should say the cause of this defect, since this defective effect is caused by something. This is what we must do, and that's exactly what needs to be done. Think about it. I have a daughter (I have her until she gets married) who's given me this letter, considering it her duty. Listen and think about this: (he reads a letter) "To the heavenly idol of my soul, the most beautified Ophelia" - By the way, "beautified" sounds bad, it sounds awful, it sounds crude, it's a terrible use of the word. But I'll go on: (he reads the letter) "In her excellent white bosom," et cetera, et cetera - you don't need to hear all this stuff - 
(he reads a letter)
(he reads the letter)

paragraphs.original: Came this from Hamlet to her?
paragraphs.translated: Hamlet wrote this letter to Ophelia?

paragraphs.original:
Good madam, stay a while. I will be faithful.
(reads the letter)
(reads the letter)
"Doubt thou the stars are fire,
Doubt thou the stars are fire
Doubt that the sun doth move,
Doubt that the sun doth move
Doubt truth to be a liar,
Doubt truth to be a liar
But never doubt I love.
But never doubt I love
O dear Ophelia, I am ill at these numbers. I have not art to reckon my groans, but that I love thee best, oh, most best, believe it. Adieu.
Thine evermore, most dear lady,
Thine evermore, most dear lady
whilst this machine is to him,
whilst this machine is to him
Hamlet."
This in obedience hath my daughter shown me,
And more above, hath his solicitings,
As they fell out by time, by means, and place,
All given to mine ear.
paragraphs.translated:
Madam, please be patient. I'll read it to you.
(he reads the letter)
(he reads the letter)
"You may wonder if the stars are fire,
You may wonder if the stars are fire
You may wonder if the sun moves across the sky.
You may wonder if the sun moves across the sky
You may wonder if the truth is a liar,
You may wonder if the truth is a liar
But never wonder if I love.
But never wonder if I love
Oh, Ophelia, I'm bad at poetry. I can't put my feelings into verse, but please believe I love you best, oh, best of all. Believe it.
Yours forever, my dearest one,
Yours forever, my dearest one,
as long as I live - still chugging along,
as long as I live - still chugging along
Hamlet."
Dutifully and obediently my daughter showed me this letter, and more like it. She's told me all about how Hamlet has been courting her - all the details of where, and what he said, and when.

paragraphs.original: But how hath she received his love?
paragraphs.translated: And how did she react to all this?

paragraphs.original: What do you think of me?
paragraphs.translated: Sir, what is your opinion of me?

paragraphs.original: As of a man faithful and honorable.
paragraphs.translated: I know you are loyal and honorable.

paragraphs.original:
I would fain prove so. But what might you think,
When I had seen this hot love on the wing - 
As I perceived it, I must tell you that,
Before my daughter told me - what might you,
Or my dear majesty your queen here, think,
If I had played the desk or table-book,
Or given my heart a winking, mute and dumb,
Or looked upon this love with idle sight?
What might you think? No, I went round to work,
And my young mistress thus I did bespeak:
"Lord Hamlet is a prince out of thy star.
This must not be." And then I prescripts gave her,
That she should lock herself from his resort,
Admit no messengers, receive no tokens.
Which done, she took the fruits of my advice;
And he, repelled - a short tale to make - 
Fell into a sadness, then into a fast,
Thence to a watch, thence into a weakness,
Thence to a lightness, and, by this declension,
Into the madness wherein now he raves
And all we mourn for.
paragraphs.translated: I would like to prove to you that I am. But what would you have thought of me if I had kept quiet when I found out about this hot little love (which I noticed even before my daughter told me about it)? My dear queen, what would you have thought of me if I had turned a blind eye to what was happening between Hamlet and my daughter? No, I had to do something. And so I said to my daughter: "Lord Hamlet is a prince, he's out of your league. You have to end this." And then I gave her orders to stay away from him, and not to accept any messages or little gifts from him. She did what I said. When she rejected Hamlet, he became sad, and stopped eating, stopped sleeping, got weak, got dizzy, and as a result lost his mind. And that's why he's crazy now, and all of us feel sorry for him.

paragraphs.original: It may be, very like.
paragraphs.translated: It may be, it certainly may be.

paragraphs.original:
Hath there been such a time - I would fain know that - 
That I have positively said, "'Tis so,"
When it proved otherwise?
paragraphs.translated: Has there ever been a time - I'd really like to know - when I've definitely said something was true, and it turned out not to be true?

paragraphs.original: Not that I know.
paragraphs.translated: Not that I know of.

paragraphs.original:
(points to his head and shoulders)
(points to his head and shoulders)
Take this from this if this be otherwise.
If circumstances lead me, I will find
Where truth is hid, though it were hid indeed
Within the center.
paragraphs.translated:
(pointing to his head and shoulders) Chop my head off if I'm wrong. I'll follow the clues and uncover the truth, even if it's at the very center of the earth.
(pointing to his head and shoulders)

paragraphs.original: How may we try it further?
paragraphs.translated: What can we do to find out if it's true?

paragraphs.original:
You know sometimes he walks four hours together
Here in the lobby.
paragraphs.translated: Well, you know he sometimes walks here in the lobby for four hours at a time.

paragraphs.original: So he does indeed.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, he does.

paragraphs.original:
At such a time I'll loose my daughter to him.
(to CLAUDIUS) Be you and I behind an arras then,
(to
)
Mark the encounter. If he love her not
And be not from his reason fall'n thereon,
Let me be no assistant for a state
But keep a farm and carters.
paragraphs.translated:
When he's there next time, I'll send my daughter to see him. (to CLAUDIUS) You and I will hide behind the
arras and watch what happens. If it turns out that Hamlet's not in love after all, and hasn't gone mad from love, then you can fire me from my court job and I'll go work on a farm.
arras

paragraphs.original: We will try it.
paragraphs.translated: We'll try what you suggest.

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET, reading on a book
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET enters, reading a book.

paragraphs.original: But look where sadly the poor wretch comes reading.
paragraphs.translated: Look how sadly he's coming in, reading his book.

paragraphs.original:
Away, I do beseech you, both away.
I'll board him presently. O, give me leave.
paragraphs.translated: Please go away, both of you. I'll speak to him now. Oh, please let me.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt CLAUDIUS and GERTRUDE
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS and GERTRUDE exit.

paragraphs.original: How does my good Lord Hamlet?
paragraphs.translated: How are you, Hamlet?

paragraphs.original: Well, God-'a'-mercy.
paragraphs.translated: Fine, thank you.

paragraphs.original: Do you know me, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know who I am?

paragraphs.original: Excellent well. You are a fishmonger.
paragraphs.translated: Of course. You sell fish.

paragraphs.original: Not I, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No, not me, sir.

paragraphs.original: Then I would you were so honest a man.
paragraphs.translated: In that case I wish you were as good a man as a fish seller.

paragraphs.original: Honest, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Good, sir?

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir. To be honest, as this world goes, is to be one man picked out of ten thousand.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, sir. Only one man in ten thousand is good in this world.

paragraphs.original: That's very true, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: That's definitely true, my lord.

paragraphs.original: For if the sun breed maggots in a dead dog, being a good kissing carrion -  Have you a daughter?
paragraphs.translated: Since if the sun breeds maggots on a dead dog, kissing the corpse - by the way, do you have a daughter?

paragraphs.original: I have, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I do indeed, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Let her not walk i' th' sun. Conception is a blessing, but, as your daughter may conceive - Friend, look to 't.
paragraphs.translated: Then by all means never let her walk in public. Procreation is a good thing, but if your daughter gets pregnant … look out, friend.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) How say you by that? Still harping on my daughter. Yet he knew me not at first. He said I was a fishmonger. He is far gone, far gone. And truly in my youth I suffered much extremity for love, very near this. I'll speak to him again. - (to HAMLET) What do you read, my lord?
(aside)
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Now, what does he mean by that? Still harping on my daughter. But he didn't recognize me at first. He mistook me for a fish seller. He's far gone. But when I was young I went crazy for love too, almost as bad as this. I'll talk to him again. - (to HAMLET) What are you reading, your highness?
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: Words, words, words.
paragraphs.translated: A lot of words.

paragraphs.original: What is the matter, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: And what is the subject?

paragraphs.original: Between who?
paragraphs.translated: Between whom?

paragraphs.original: I mean, the matter that you read, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I mean, what do the words say?

paragraphs.original: Slanders, sir. For the satirical rogue says here that old men have gray beards, that their faces are wrinkled, their eyes purging thick amber and plum-tree gum, and that they have a plentiful lack of wit, together with most weak hams - all which, sir, though I most powerfully and potently believe, yet I hold it not honesty to have it thus set down; for yourself, sir, should be old as I am, if like a crab you could go backward.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, just lies, sir. The sly writer says here that old men have gray beards, their faces are wrinkled, their eyes full of gunk, and that they have no wisdom and weak thighs. Of course I believe it all, but I don't think it's good manners to write it down, since you yourself, sir, would grow as old as I am, if you could only travel backward like a crab.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Though this be madness, yet there is method in 't. - (to HAMLET) Will you walk out of the air, my lord?
(aside)
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) There's a method to his madness. (to HAMLET) Will you step outside, my lord?
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: Into my grave.
paragraphs.translated: Into my grave.

paragraphs.original:
Indeed, that is out of the air. (aside) How pregnant sometimes his replies are. A happiness that often madness hits on, which reason and sanity could not so prosperously be delivered of. I will leave him and suddenly contrive the means of meeting between him and my daughter. - (to HAMLET) My honorable lord, I will most humbly take my leave of you.
(aside)
(to
)
paragraphs.translated:
Well, that's certainly out of this world, all right. (to himself) His answers are so full of meaning sometimes! He has a way with words, as crazy people often do, and that sane people don't have a talent for. I'll leave him now and arrange a meeting between him and my daughter. (to HAMLET) My lord, I'll
take my leave of you now.
(to himself)
(to
)
take my leave

paragraphs.original: You cannot, sir, take from me any thing that I will more willingly part withal - except my life, except my life, except my life.
paragraphs.translated: You can't take anything from me that I care less about - except my life, except my life, except my life.

paragraphs.original: Fare you well, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Good-bye, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) These tedious old fools!
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) These boring old fools!
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN enter.

paragraphs.original: You go to seek the Lord Hamlet. There he is.
paragraphs.translated: You're looking for Lord Hamlet. He's right over there.

paragraphs.original: God save you, sir!
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, sir.

paragraphs.original: Exit POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: My honored lord!
paragraphs.translated: My lord!

paragraphs.original: My most dear lord!
paragraphs.translated: My dear sir!

paragraphs.original:
My excellent good friends! How dost thou, Guildenstern?
Ah, Rosencrantz! Good lads, how do you both?
paragraphs.translated:
Ah, my good old friends! How are you, Guildenstern?
And Rosencrantz! Boys, how are you both doing?

paragraphs.original: As the indifferent children of the earth.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, as well as anybody.

paragraphs.original:
Happy, in that we are not overhappy.
On Fortune's cap we are not the very button.
paragraphs.translated: Happy that we're not too happy, lucky in being not too lucky. We're not exactly at the top of our luck.

paragraphs.original: Nor the soles of her shoes?
paragraphs.translated: But you're not down and out, either, are you?

paragraphs.original: Neither, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No, we're just somewhere in the middle, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Then you live about her waist, or in the middle of her favors?
paragraphs.translated: So you're around Lady Luck's waist?

paragraphs.original: Faith, her privates we.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, we're the privates in her army.

paragraphs.original: In the secret parts of Fortune? Oh, most true. She is a strumpet. What news?
paragraphs.translated: Ha, ha, so you've gotten into her private parts? Of course - Lady Luck is such a slut. Anyway, what's up?

paragraphs.original: None, my lord, but that the world's grown honest.
paragraphs.translated: Not much, my lord. Just that the world's become honest.

paragraphs.original: Then is doomsday near. But your news is not true. Let me question more in particular. What have you, my good friends, deserved at the hands of fortune that she sends you to prison hither?
paragraphs.translated: In that case, the end of the world is approaching. But you're wrong. Let me ask you a particular question. What crimes have you committed to be sent here to this prison?

paragraphs.original: Prison, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Prison, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Denmark's a prison.
paragraphs.translated: Denmark's a prison.

paragraphs.original: Then is the world one.
paragraphs.translated: Then I guess the whole world is one.

paragraphs.original: A goodly one, in which there are many confines, wards, and dungeons, Denmark being one o' th' worst.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, quite a large one, with many cells and dungeons, Denmark being one of the worst.

paragraphs.original: We think not so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: We don't think so, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Why, then, 'tis none to you, for there is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so. To me it is a prison.
paragraphs.translated: Well, then it isn't one to you, since nothing is really good or bad in itself - it's all what a person thinks about it. And to me, Denmark is a prison.

paragraphs.original: Why then, your ambition makes it one. 'Tis too narrow for your mind.
paragraphs.translated: That must be because you're so ambitious. It's too small for your large mind.

paragraphs.original: O God, I could be bounded in a nutshell and count myself a king of infinite space, were it not that I have bad dreams.
paragraphs.translated: Small? No, I could live in a walnut shell and feel like the king of the universe. The real problem is that I have bad dreams.

paragraphs.original: Which dreams indeed are ambition, for the very substance of the ambitious is merely the shadow of a dream.
paragraphs.translated: Dreams are a sign of ambition, since ambition is nothing more than the shadow of a dream.

paragraphs.original: A dream itself is but a shadow.
paragraphs.translated: But a dream itself is just a shadow.

paragraphs.original: Truly, and I hold ambition of so airy and light a quality that it is but a shadow's shadow.
paragraphs.translated: Exactly. In fact, I consider ambition to be so light and airy that it's only the shadow of a shadow.

paragraphs.original: Then are our beggars bodies, and our monarchs and outstretched heroes the beggars' shadows. Shall we to th' court? For by my fay, I cannot reason.
paragraphs.translated: Then I guess beggars are the ones with bodies, while ambitious kings and heroes are just the shadows of beggars. Should we go inside? I seem to be losing my mind a bit.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN
We'll wait upon you.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN
We're at your service, whatever you say.

paragraphs.original: No such matter. I will not sort you with the rest of my servants, for, to speak to you like an honest man, I am most dreadfully attended. But in the beaten way of friendship, what make you at Elsinore?
paragraphs.translated: No, no, I won't class you with my servants, since - to be frank with you - my servants are terrible. But tell me as my friends, what are you doing here at Elsinore?

paragraphs.original: To visit you, my lord, no other occasion.
paragraphs.translated: Visiting you, my lord. There's no other reason.

paragraphs.original: Beggar that I am, I am even poor in thanks; but I thank you, and sure, dear friends, my thanks are too dear a halfpenny. Were you not sent for? Is it your own inclining? Is it a free visitation? Come, come, deal justly with me. Come, come. Nay, speak.
paragraphs.translated: Well, then, I thank you, though I'm such a beggar that even my thanks are not worth much. Did someone tell you to visit me? Or was it just your whim, on your own initiative? Come on, tell me the truth.

paragraphs.original: What should we say, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What should we say, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Why, any thing, but to th' purpose. You were sent for, and there is a kind of confession in your looks which your modesties have not craft enough to color. I know the good king and queen have sent for you.
paragraphs.translated: Anything you like, as long as it answers my question. You were sent for. You've got a guilty look on your faces, which you're too honest to disguise. I know the king and queen sent for you.

paragraphs.original: To what end, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Why would they do that, my lord?

paragraphs.original: That you must teach me. But let me conjure you, by the rights of our fellowship, by the consonancy of our youth, by the obligation of our ever-preserved love, and by what more dear a better proposer could charge you withal: be even and direct with me whether you were sent for or no.
paragraphs.translated: That's what I want you to tell me. Let me remind you of our old friendship, our youth spent together, the duties of our love for each other, and whatever else will make you answer me straight.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Nay, then, I have an eye of you - If you love me, hold not off.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) I've got my eye on you. (to GUILDENSTERN) If you care about me, you'll be honest with me.
(to himself)
(to
)

paragraphs.original: My lord, we were sent for.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, we were sent for.

paragraphs.original: I will tell you why. So shall my anticipation prevent your discovery, and your secrecy to the king and queen moult no feather. I have of late - but wherefore I know not - lost all my mirth, forgone all custom of exercises, and indeed it goes so heavily with my disposition that this goodly frame, the earth, seems to me a sterile promontory; this most excellent canopy, the air - look you, this brave o'erhanging firmament, this majestical roof fretted with golden fire - why, it appears no other thing to me than a foul and pestilent congregation of vapors. What a piece of work is a man! How noble in reason, how infinite in faculty! In form and moving how express and admirable! In action how like an angel, in apprehension how like a god! The beauty of the world. The paragon of animals. And yet, to me, what is this quintessence of dust? Man delights not me. No, nor woman neither, though by your smiling you seem to say so.
paragraphs.translated:
I'll tell you why - so you won't have to tell me and give away any secrets you have with the king and queen. Recently, though I don't know why, I've lost all sense of fun, stopped exercising - the whole world feels sterile and empty. This beautiful canopy we call the sky - this majestic roof decorated with golden sunlight - why, it's nothing more to me than disease-filled air. What a perfect invention a human is, how noble in his capacity to reason, how unlimited in thinking, how admirable in his shape and movement, how angelic in action, how godlike in understanding! There's nothing more beautiful. We surpass all other animals. And yet to me, what are we but dust? Men don't interest me. No - women neither, but you're smiling, so you must think they do.
me

paragraphs.original: My lord, there was no such stuff in my thoughts.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I wasn't thinking anything like that.

paragraphs.original: Why did you laugh then, when I said "man delights not me"?
paragraphs.translated: So why did you laugh when I said that men don't interest me?

paragraphs.original: To think, my lord, if you delight not in man, what Lenten entertainment the players shall receive from you. We coted them on the way, and hither are they coming to offer you service.
paragraphs.translated: I was just thinking that if people don't interest you, you'll be pretty bored by the actors on their way here. We crossed paths with a drama company just a while ago, and they're coming to entertain you.

paragraphs.original: He that plays the king shall be welcome. His majesty shall have tribute of me. The adventurous knight shall use his foil and target, the lover shall not sigh gratis, the humorous man shall end his part in peace, the clown shall make those laugh whose lungs are tickle o' th' sear, and the lady shall say her mind freely, or the blank verse shall halt for 't. What players are they?
paragraphs.translated: The one who plays the part of the king will be particularly welcome. I'll treat him like a real king. The adventurous knight will wave around his sword and shield, the lover will be rewarded for his sighs, the crazy character can rant all he wants, the clown will make everybody laugh, and the lady character can say whatever's on her mind, or I'll stop the play. Which troupe is it?

paragraphs.original: Even those you were wont to take delight in, the tragedians of the city.
paragraphs.translated: The tragic actors from the city, the ones you used to enjoy so much.

paragraphs.original: How chances it they travel? Their residence, both in reputation and profit, was better both ways.
paragraphs.translated: What are they doing on the road? They made more money and got more attention in the city.

paragraphs.original: I think their inhibition comes by the means of the late innovation.
paragraphs.translated: But things have changed there, and it's easier for them on the road now.

paragraphs.original: Do they hold the same estimation they did when I was in the city? Are they so followed?
paragraphs.translated: Are they as popular as they used to be when I lived in the city? Do they attract big audiences?

paragraphs.original: No, indeed are they not.
paragraphs.translated: No, not like before.

paragraphs.original: How comes it? Do they grow rusty?
paragraphs.translated: Why? Are they getting rusty?

paragraphs.original: Nay, their endeavor keeps in the wonted pace. But there is, sir, an eyrie of children, little eyases, that cry out on the top of question and are most tyrannically clapped for 't. These are now the fashion, and so berattle the common stages - so they call them - that many wearing rapiers are afraid of goose quills and dare scarce come thither.
paragraphs.translated: No, they're busy and as excellent as ever. The problem is that they have to compete with a group of children who yell out their lines and receive outrageous applause for it. These child actors are now in fashion, and they've so overtaken the public theaters that society types hardly come at all, they're so afraid of being mocked by the playwrights who write for the boys.

paragraphs.original: What, are they children? Who maintains 'em? How are they escoted? Will they pursue the quality no longer than they can sing? Will they not say afterwards, if they should grow themselves to common players (as it is most like if their means are no better), their writers do them wrong to make them exclaim against their own succession?
paragraphs.translated: What, you mean kid actors? Who takes care of them? Who pays their way? Will they stop working when their voices mature? Aren't the playwrights hurting them by making them upstage adult actors, which they are going to grow up and become? (Unless, of course, they have trust funds.)

paragraphs.original: Faith, there has been much to do on both sides, and the nation holds it no sin to tar them to controversy. There was, for a while, no money bid for argument unless the poet and the player went to cuffs in the question.
paragraphs.translated: There's been a whole debate on the topic. For a while, no play was sold to the theaters without a big fight between the children's playwright and the actors playing adult roles.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated: Are you kidding?

paragraphs.original: Oh, there has been much throwing about of brains.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, there's been a lot of quarreling.

paragraphs.original: Do the boys carry it away?
paragraphs.translated: And the boys are winning so far?

paragraphs.original: Ay, that they do, my lord. Hercules and his load too.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, they are, my lord - little boys are carrying the whole theater on their backs, like Hercules carried the world.

paragraphs.original: It is not very strange. For my uncle is King of Denmark, and those that would make mouths at him while my father lived give twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for his picture in little. 'Sblood, there is something in this more than natural, if philosophy could find it out.
paragraphs.translated: Actually, it's not so unusual when you think about it. My uncle is king of Denmark, and the same people who made fun of him while my father was still alive are now rushing to pay twenty, forty, fifty, a hundred ducats apiece for miniature portraits of him. There's something downright unnatural about it, if a philosopher stopped to think about it.

paragraphs.original: Flourish for the PLAYERS within
paragraphs.translated:
Trumpets play offstage, announcing the arrival of the
PLAYERS .

paragraphs.original: There are the players.
paragraphs.translated: The actors are here.

paragraphs.original: Gentlemen, you are welcome to Elsinore. Your hands, come then. Th' appurtenance of welcome is fashion and ceremony. Let me comply with you in this garb - lest my extent to the players, which, I tell you, must show fairly outwards, should more appear like entertainment than yours. You are welcome. But my uncle-father and aunt-mother are deceived.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, welcome to Elsinore. Don't be shy - shake hands with me. If I'm going to welcome you I have to go through all these polite customs, don't I? And if we don't shake hands, when I act all nice to the players it will seem like I'm happier to see them than you. You are very welcome here. But still, my uncle-father and aunt-mother have got the wrong idea.

paragraphs.original: In what, my dear lord?
paragraphs.translated: In what sense, my lord?

paragraphs.original: I am but mad north-north-west. When the wind is southerly, I know a hawk from a handsaw.
paragraphs.translated: I'm only crazy sometimes. At other times, I know what's what.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS enters.

paragraphs.original: Well be with you, gentlemen.
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen, I hope you are well.

paragraphs.original: Happily he's the second time come to them, for they say an old man is twice a child.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, the second time around, since, as they say, old people become children again.

paragraphs.original: My lord, I have news to tell you.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I have news for you.

paragraphs.original: My lord, I have news to tell you. When Roscius was an actor in Rome -
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I have news for you. When Roscius was an actor in ancient Rome  -

paragraphs.original: The actors are come hither, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: The actors have arrived, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Buzz, buzz.
paragraphs.translated: Yawn, snore.

paragraphs.original: Upon my honor -
paragraphs.translated: I swear -

paragraphs.original: Then came each actor on his ass -
paragraphs.translated: - each actor arrived on his ass.

paragraphs.original: The best actors in the world, either for tragedy, comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical, historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-comical-historical-pastoral, scene individable, or poem unlimited. Seneca cannot be too heavy, nor Plautus too light. For the law of writ and the liberty, these are the only men.
paragraphs.translated:
They are the best actors in the world, either for
tragedy, comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical, historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-comical-historical, one-act plays, or long poems. The tragic playwright Seneca is not too heavy for them to handle nor is the comic writer Plautus too light. For formal plays or freer dramas, these are the best actors around.
tragedy, comedy, history, pastoral, pastoral-comical, historical-pastoral, tragical-historical, tragical-comical-historical, one-act plays, or long poems

paragraphs.original: O Jephthah, judge of Israel, what a treasure hadst thou!
paragraphs.translated:
Oh,
Jephthah, judge of ancient Israel, what a treasure you had!
Jephthah

paragraphs.original: What a treasure had he, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What treasure did he have, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Why,
One fair daughter and no more,
One fair daughter and no more
The which he lovèd passing well.
The which he lovèd passing well
paragraphs.translated:
Well, (sings)
(sings)
One fine daughter, and no more,
One fine daughter, and no more
Whom he loved more than anything - .
Whom he loved more than anything

paragraphs.original:
(aside) Still on my daughter.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Still talking about my daughter, I see.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: Am I not i' th' right, old Jephthah?
paragraphs.translated: Aren't I right, Jephthah, old man?

paragraphs.original: If you call me Jephthah, my lord, I have a daughter that I love passing well.
paragraphs.translated: If you're calling me Jephthah, my lord, I do have a daughter I love more than anything, yes.

paragraphs.original: Nay, that follows not.
paragraphs.translated:
No, that's not logical.
No, that's not logical.

paragraphs.original: What follows, then, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What is logical, then, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Why,
paragraphs.translated: Why,

paragraphs.original:
As by lot, God wot, and then, you know,  It came to pass, as most like it was -  The first row of the pious chanson will show you more, for look where my abridgement comes.
As by lot, God wot,
It came to pass, as most like it was -
paragraphs.translated:
As if by chance, God knows,
As if by chance, God knows
and then, you know,
It happened, as you'd expect - 
It happened, as you'd expect
If you want to know more, you can refer to the popular song, because now I have to stop.

paragraphs.original: Enter the PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: The PLAYERS enter.

paragraphs.original: You are welcome, masters, welcome, all! - I am glad to see thee well. - Welcome, good friends. - O old friend? Why, thy face is valenced since I saw thee last. Comest thou to beard me in Denmark? - What, my young lady and mistress! By 'r Lady, your ladyship is nearer to heaven than when I saw you last, by the altitude of a chopine. Pray God, your voice, like a piece of uncurrent gold, be not cracked within the ring. - Masters, you are all welcome. We'll e'en to 't like French falconers, fly at any thing we see. We'll have a speech straight. Come, give us a taste of your quality. Come, a passionate speech.
paragraphs.translated:
Welcome, welcome to all of you. (he turns to one of the actors) - Oh, you, I'm glad to see you. (turns back to all of them) - Welcome, my good friends. (turns to another actor) - Oh, it's you! You've grown a beard since I saw you last. Are you going to put a beard on me too?
(turns to an actor dressed as a woman)  - Well hello, my young lady friend. You've grown as much as the height of a pair of platform shoes at least! I hope your voice hasn't changed yet. (to the whole company) - All of you are most welcome here. We'll get right to business. First, a speech. Come on, give us a little speech to whet our appetites. A passionate speech, please.
(he turns to one of the actors)
(turns back to all of them)
(turns to another actor)
(turns to an actor dressed as a woman)
(turns to an actor dressed as a woman)



(to the whole company)

paragraphs.original: What speech, my good lord?
paragraphs.translated: Which speech, my lord?

paragraphs.original: I heard thee speak me a speech once, but it was never acted. Or, if it was, not above once, for the play, I remember, pleased not the million. 'Twas caviary to the general. But it was - as I received it, and others, whose judgments in such matters cried in the top of mine - an excellent play, well digested in the scenes, set down with as much modesty as cunning.
paragraphs.translated: I heard you recite a speech for me once that was never acted out, or if it was, it was performed only once, since the play was not popular - like caviar for a slob who couldn't appreciate it. But the critics and I found it to be an excellent play, with well-ordered scenes that were clever but not fancy.

paragraphs.original:
I remember, one said there were no sallets in the lines to make the matter savory, nor no matter in the phrase that might indict the author of affectation, but called it an honest method, as wholesome as sweet, and by very much more handsome than fine. One speech in it I chiefly loved. 'Twas Aeneas' tale to Dido and thereabout of it, especially where he speaks of Priam's slaughter. If it live in your >memory, begin at this line - Let me see, let me see - 
The rugged Pyrrhus, like th' Hyrcanian beast - 
The rugged Pyrrhus, like th' Hyrcanian beast
It is not so. It begins with Pyrrhus - 
The rugged Pyrrhus, he whose sable arms,
The rugged Pyrrhus, he whose sable arms
Black as his purpose, did the night resemble
Black as his purpose, did the night resemble
When he lay couchèd in the ominous horse,
When he lay couchèd in the ominous horse
Hath now this dread and black complexion smeared
Hath now this dread and black complexion smeared
With heraldry more dismal. Head to foot
With heraldry more dismal. Head to foot
Now is he total gules, horridly tricked
Now is he total gules, horridly tricked
With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons,
With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons
Baked and impasted with the parching streets,
Baked and impasted with the parching streets
That lend a tyrannous and damnèd light
That lend a tyrannous and damnèd light
To their lord's murder. Roasted in wrath and fire,
To their lord's murder. Roasted in wrath and fire
And thus o'ersizèd with coagulate gore,
And thus o'ersizèd with coagulate gore
With eyes like carbuncles, the hellish Pyrrhus
With eyes like carbuncles, the hellish Pyrrhus
Old grandsire Priam seeks.
Old grandsire Priam seeks
So, proceed you.
paragraphs.translated:
I remember one critic said there was no vulgar language to spice up the dialogue, and showing off on playwright's part. That critic called it an excellent play, containing things to reflect upon as well as sweet music to enjoy. I loved one speech in particular. It was when
Aeneas told Dido about Priam's murder. If you happen to remember this scene, begin at line - let me see, how does it go?
Aeneas told Dido about Priam's



The rugged
Pyrrhus, strong as a tiger - 
The rugged
Pyrrhus,
Pyrrhus



strong as a tiger - 
No, that's wrong; it begins like this:
Savage Pyrrhus, whose black armor was
Savage Pyrrhus, whose black armor was
As dark plans, and was like the night
As dark plans, and was like the night
When he crouched inside the Trojan Horse,
When he crouched inside the Trojan Horse
Has now smeared his dark armor
Has now smeared his dark armor
With something worse. From head to foot
With something worse. From head to foot
He's now covered in red, decorated horribly
He's now covered in red, decorated horribly
With the blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons.
With the blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons
The blood is baked to a paste by fires he set in the streets,
The blood is baked to a paste by fires he set in the streets
Fires that lend a terrible light to his horrible murders.
Fires that lend a terrible light to his horrible murders
Boiling with anger and fire,
Boiling with anger and fire
And coated thick with hard-baked blood,
And coated thick with hard-baked blood
His eyes glowing like rubies, the hellish Pyrrhus
His eyes glowing like rubies, the hellish Pyrrhus
Goes looking for grandfather Priam.
Goes looking for grandfather Priam
Sir, take it from there.

paragraphs.original: 'Fore God, my lord, well spoken, with good accent and good discretion.
paragraphs.translated: My God, that was well done, my lord, with the right accent and a good ear.

paragraphs.original:
Anon he finds him
Anon he finds him
Striking too short at Greeks. His antique sword,
Striking too short at Greeks. His antique sword
Rebellious to his arm, lies where it falls,
Rebellious to his arm, lies where it falls
Repugnant to command. Unequal matched,
Repugnant to command. Unequal matched
Pyrrhus at Priam drives, in rage strikes wide,
Pyrrhus at Priam drives, in rage strikes wide
But with the whiff and wind of his fell sword
But with the whiff and wind of his fell sword
The unnerved father falls. Then senseless Ilium,
The unnerved father falls. Then senseless Ilium
Seeming to feel this blow, with flaming top
Seeming to feel this blow, with flaming top
Stoops to his base, and with a hideous crash
Stoops to his base, and with a hideous crash
Takes prisoner Pyrrhus' ear. For, lo, his sword,
Takes prisoner Pyrrhus' ear. For, lo, his sword
Which was declining on the milky head
Which was declining on the milky head
Of reverend Priam, seemed i' th' air to stick.
Of reverend Priam, seemed i' th' air to stick
So as a painted tyrant Pyrrhus stood,
So as a painted tyrant Pyrrhus stood
paragraphs.translated:
Soon he finds Priam
Soon he finds Priam
Failing in his battle against the Greeks. His old sword,
Failing in his battle against the Greeks. His old sword
Which Priam cannot wield anymore, lies where it fell.
Which Priam cannot wield anymore, lies where it fell
An unfair opponent,
An unfair opponent
Pyrrhus rushes at Priam, and in his rage he misses;
Pyrrhus rushes at Priam, and in his rage he misses;

paragraphs.original:
And, like a neutral to his will and matter,
And, like a neutral to his will and matter
Did nothing.
Did nothing
But as we often see against some storm
But as we often see against some storm
A silence in the heavens, the rack stand still,
A silence in the heavens, the rack stand still
The bold winds speechless, and the orb below
The bold winds speechless, and the orb below
As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder
As hush as death, anon the dreadful thunder
Doth rend the region. So, after Pyrrhus' pause,
Doth rend the region. So, after Pyrrhus' pause
Arousèd vengeance sets him new a-work.
Arousèd vengeance sets him new a-work
And never did the Cyclops' hammers fall
And never did the Cyclops' hammers fall
On Mars's armor forged for proof eterne
On Mars's armor forged for proof eterne
With less remorse than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword
With less remorse than Pyrrhus' bleeding sword
Now falls on Priam.
Now falls on Priam
Out, out, thou strumpet Fortune! All you gods
Out, out, thou strumpet Fortune! All you gods
In general synod take away her power,
In general synod take away her power
Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel,
Break all the spokes and fellies from her wheel
And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven,
And bowl the round nave down the hill of heaven
As low as to the fiends!
As low as to the fiends!
paragraphs.translated:
But the wind created by his sword is enough to make
But the wind created by his sword is enough to make
The weakened old man fall. Just then the city of Ilium,
The weakened old man fall. Just then the city of Ilium
As if feeling this fatal blow to its ruler,
As if feeling this fatal blow to its ruler
Collapses in flames, and the crash
Collapses in flames, and the crash
Captures Pyrrhus's attention. His sword,
Captures Pyrrhus's attention. His sword
Which was falling onto Priam's white-haired head
Which was falling onto Priam's white-haired head
Seemed to hang in the air.
Seemed to hang in the air
Pyrrhus stood there like a man in a painting,
Pyrrhus stood there like a man in a painting
Doing nothing.
Doing nothing
But just as a raging thunderstorm
But just as a raging thunderstorm
Is often interrupted by a moment's silence,
Is often interrupted by a moment's silence
And then soon after the region is split apart by dreadful thunderclaps,
And then soon after the region is split apart by dreadful thunderclaps
In the same way, after Pyrrhus paused,
In the same way, after Pyrrhus paused
His newly awakened fury set him to work again.
His newly awakened fury set him to work again
When the Cyclopses were making unbreakable armor
When the Cyclopses were making unbreakable armor
For the god of war, their hammers never fell
For the god of war, their hammers never fell
So mercilessly as Pyrrhus's bloody sword
So mercilessly as Pyrrhus's bloody sword
Now falls on Priam.
Now falls on Priam
Get out of here, Lady Luck, you whore! All you gods
Get out of here, Lady Luck, you whore! All you gods
Should come together to rob her of her powers,
Should come together to rob her of her powers
Break all the spokes on her wheel of fortune,
Break all the spokes on her wheel of fortune
And send it rolling down the hills of heaven
And send it rolling down the hills of heaven
Into the depths of hell.
Into the depths of hell

paragraphs.original: This is too long.
paragraphs.translated: This speech is going on too long.

paragraphs.original: It shall to the barber's, with your beard. - Prithee, say on. He's for a jig or a tale of bawdry, or he sleeps. Say on. Come to Hecuba.
paragraphs.translated: We'll have the barber trim it later, along with your beard. Please, continue, players. This old man only likes the dancing or the sex scenes; he sleeps through all the rest. Go on, come to the part about Hecuba.

paragraphs.original:
But who, ah woe, who had seen the moblèd queen - 
But who, ah woe, who had seen the moblèd queen
paragraphs.translated:
But who - ah, the sadness - had seen the muffled queen - 
But who - ah, the sadness - had seen the muffled queen -

paragraphs.original: "The moblèd queen"?
paragraphs.translated: "The muffled queen"?

paragraphs.original: That's good. "Moblèd queen" is good.
paragraphs.translated: That's good. "The muffled queen" is good.

paragraphs.original:
Run barefoot up and down, threatening the flames
Run barefoot up and down, threatening the flames
With bisson rheum, a clout upon that head
With bisson rheum, a clout upon that head
Where late the diadem stood, and for a robe,
Where late the diadem stood, and for a robe
About her lank and all o'erteemèd loins,
About her lank and all o'erteemèd loins
A blanket, in the alarm of fear caught up - 
A blanket, in the alarm of fear caught up
Who this had seen, with tongue in venom steeped,
Who this had seen, with tongue in venom steeped
'Gainst fortune's state would treason have pronounced.
'Gainst fortune's state would treason have pronounced
But if the gods themselves did see her then
But if the gods themselves did see her then
When she saw Pyrrhus make malicious sport
When she saw Pyrrhus make malicious sport
In mincing with his sword her husband's limbs,
In mincing with his sword her husband's limbs
The instant burst of clamor that she made,
The instant burst of clamor that she made
(Unless things mortal move them not at all)
(Unless things mortal move them not at all)
Would have made milch the burning eyes of heaven,
Would have made milch the burning eyes of heaven
And passion in the gods.
And passion in the gods
paragraphs.translated:
Running back and forth, spraying the flames with her tears, a cloth on that head where a crown had recently sat and a blanket instead of a robe wrapped around her body, which has withered from childbearing: anyone seeing her in such a state, no matter how spiteful he was, would have cursed Lady Luck for bringing her down like that. If the gods had seen her while she watched Pyrrhus chopping her husband into bits, the terrible cry she uttered would have made all the eyes in heaven burn with hot tears - unless the gods don't care at all about human affairs.
Running back and forth, spraying the flames with her tears, a cloth on that head where a crown had recently sat and a blanket instead of a robe wrapped around her body, which has withered from childbearing: anyone seeing her in such a state, no matter how spiteful he was, would have cursed Lady Luck for bringing her down like that. If the gods had seen her while she watched Pyrrhus chopping her husband into bits, the terrible cry she uttered would have made all the eyes in heaven burn with hot tears - unless the gods don't care at all about human affairs

paragraphs.original: Look whe'e he has not turned his color and has tears in 's eyes. - Prithee, no more.
paragraphs.translated: Look how flushed the actor is, with tears in his eyes. All right, that's enough, please.

paragraphs.original: My lord, I will use them according to their desert.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I will give them all they deserve.

paragraphs.original: God's bodykins, man, much better. Use every man after his desert, and who should 'scape whipping? Use them after your own honor and dignity. The less they deserve, the more merit is in your bounty. Take them in.
paragraphs.translated:
Good heavens, man, give them more than that! If you pay everyone what they deserve, would anyone ever escape a whipping? Treat them with honor and dignity.
The less they deserve, the more your generosity is worth. Lead them inside.

paragraphs.original: Come, sirs.
paragraphs.translated: Come, everyone.

paragraphs.original:
Follow him, friends. We'll hear a play tomorrow. (to FIRST PLAYER) -  Dost thou hear me, old friend? Can you play The Murder of Gonzago?
(to
)
The
Murder of Gonzago
paragraphs.translated:
Follow him, friends. We'll watch a whole play tomorrow. (to FIRST PLAYER) My friend, can you perform The Murder of Gonzago?
(to
)
The Murder of Gonzago

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: We'll ha 't tomorrow night. You could, for a need, study a speech of some dozen or sixteen lines which I would set down and insert in 't, could you not?
paragraphs.translated: Then we'll see that tomorrow night. By the way, if I were to compose an extra speech of twelve to sixteen lines and stick it into the play, you could learn it by heart for tomorrow, right?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Very well. Follow that lord, and look you mock him not.
paragraphs.translated: Very well. Follow that gentleman now, and be careful not to make fun of him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt POLONIUS and the PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS and the PLAYERS exit.

paragraphs.original: My good friends, I'll leave you till night. You are welcome to Elsinore.
paragraphs.translated: My good friends, I'll see you tomorrow. Welcome to Elsinore.

paragraphs.original: Good my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Ay, so. Good-bye to you.
paragraphs.translated: Ah yes, good-bye to you both.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.

paragraphs.original:
Now I am alone.
Oh, what a rogue and peasant slave am I!
Is it not monstrous that this player here,
But in a fiction, in a dream of passion,
Could force his soul so to his own conceit
That from her working all his visage wanned,
Tears in his eyes, distraction in his aspect,
A broken voice, and his whole function suiting
With forms to his conceit? And all for nothing - 
For Hecuba!
What's Hecuba to him or he to Hecuba
That he should weep for her? What would he do
Had he the motive and the cue for passion
That I have? He would drown the stage with tears
And cleave the general ear with horrid speech,
Make mad the guilty and appall the free,
paragraphs.translated: Now I'm alone. Oh, what a mean low-life I am! It's awful that this actor could force his soul to feel made-up feelings in a work of make-believe. He grew pale, shed real tears, became overwhelmed, his voice breaking with feeling and his whole being, even, meeting the needs of his act - and all for nothing. For Hecuba!

paragraphs.original:
Confound the ignorant, and amaze indeed
The very faculties of eyes and ears. Yet I,
A dull and muddy-mettled rascal, peak
Like John-a-dreams, unpregnant of my cause,
And can say nothing - no, not for a king,
Upon whose property and most dear life
A damned defeat was made. Am I a coward?
Who calls me "villain"? Breaks my pate across?
Plucks off my beard and blows it in my face?
Tweaks me by the nose? Gives me the lie i' th' throat
As deep as to the lungs? Who does me this?
Ha!
'Swounds, I should take it, for it cannot be
But I am pigeon-livered and lack gall
To make oppression bitter, or ere this
I should have fatted all the region kites
With this slave's offal. Bloody, bawdy villain!
Remorseless, treacherous, lecherous, kindless villain!

O vengeance!
Why, what an ass am I! This is most brave,
That I, the son of a dear father murdered,
Prompted to my revenge by heaven and hell,
Must, like a whore, unpack my heart with words
And fall a-cursing like a very drab,
A scullion! Fie upon 't, foh!
About, my brain. - Hum, I have heard
That guilty creatures sitting at a play
Have, by the very cunning of the scene,
Been struck so to the soul that presently
They have proclaimed their malefactions.
For murder, though it have no tongue, will speak
With most miraculous organ. I'll have these players
Play something like the murder of my father
Before mine uncle. I'll observe his looks.
I'll tent him to the quick. If he do blench,
I know my course. The spirit that I have seen
paragraphs.translated: What is Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba, that he would weep for her? Just imagine what he would do if he had the cause for feeling that I do. He would drown the stage with his tears and burst the audience's ears with his terrible words, drive the guilty spectators crazy, terrify the innocent ones, confuse the ignorant ones, and astound absolutely everyone's eyes and ears. But what do I, a grim and uncourageous rascal, do? Mope around like a dreamer, not even bothering with plans for revenge, and I can say nothing - nothing at all - on behalf of a king whose dear life was stolen. Am I a coward? Is there anyone out there who'll call me "villain" and slap me hard? Pull off my beard? Pinch my nose? Call me the worst liar? By God, if someone would do that to me, I'd take it, because I'm a lily-livered man - otherwise, I would've fattened up the local vultures with the intestines of that low-life king a long time ago. Bloody, inhuman villain! Remorseless, treacherous, sex-obsessed, unnatural villain! Ah, revenge! What an ass I am. I'm so damn brave. My dear father's been murdered, and I've been urged to seek revenge by heaven and hell, and yet all I can do is stand around cursing like a whore in the streets. Damn it! I need to get myself together here! Hmm…. I've heard that guilty people watching a play have been so affected by the artistry of the scene that they are driven to confess their crimes out loud.

paragraphs.original:
May be the devil, and the devil hath power
T' assume a pleasing shape. Yea, and perhaps
Out of my weakness and my melancholy,
As he is very potent with such spirits,
Abuses me to damn me. I'll have grounds
More relative than this. The play's the thing
Wherein I'll catch the conscience of the king.
paragraphs.translated: Murder has no tongue, but miraculously it still finds a way to speak. I'll have these actors perform something like my father's murder in front of my uncle. I'll watch my uncle. I'll probe his conscience and see if he flinches. If he becomes pale, I know what to do. The ghost I saw may be the devil, and the devil has the power to assume a pleasing disguise, and so he may be taking advantage of my weakness and sadness to bring about my damnation. I need better evidence than the ghost to work with. The play's the thing to uncover the conscience of the king.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLAUDIUS, GERTRUDE, POLONIUS, OPHELIA, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS, GERTRUDE, POLONIUS, OPHELIA, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN enter.

paragraphs.original:
And can you by no drift of conference
Get from him why he puts on this confusion,
Grating so harshly all his days of quiet
With turbulent and dangerous lunacy?
paragraphs.translated: And you can't put your heads together and figure out why he's acting so dazed and confused, ruining his peace and quiet with such dangerous displays of lunacy?

paragraphs.original:
He does confess he feels himself distracted.
But from what cause he will by no means speak.
