paragraphs.translated: He admits he feels confused, but refuses to say why.

paragraphs.original:
Nor do we find him forward to be sounded.
But with a crafty madness keeps aloof
When we would bring him on to some confession
Of his true state.
paragraphs.translated: And he's not exactly eager to be interrogated. He's very sly and dances around our questions when we try to get him to talk about how he feels.

paragraphs.original: Did he receive you well?
paragraphs.translated: Did he treat you well when you saw him?

paragraphs.original: Most like a gentleman.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, in a very gentlemanly way.

paragraphs.original: But with much forcing of his disposition.
paragraphs.translated: But it seemed like he had to force himself to be nice to us.

paragraphs.original:
Niggard of question, but of our demands
Most free in his reply.
paragraphs.translated: He didn't ask questions, but answered ours at length.

paragraphs.original:
Did you assay him?
To any pastime?
paragraphs.translated: Did you try tempting him with some entertainment?

paragraphs.original:
Madam, it so fell out, that certain players
We o'erraught on the way. Of these we told him,
And there did seem in him a kind of joy
paragraphs.translated: Madam, some actors happened to cross our paths on the way here. We told Hamlet about them, and that seemed to do him good.

paragraphs.original:
To hear of it. They are about the court,
And, as I think, they have already order
This night to play before him.
paragraphs.translated: They are here at court now, and I believe they've been told to give a performance for him tonight.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis most true,
And he beseeched me to entreat your Majesties
To hear and see the matter.
paragraphs.translated: It's true, and he asked me to beg you both to attend.

paragraphs.original:
With all my heart, and it doth much content me
To hear him so inclined.
Good gentlemen, give him a further edge,
And drive his purpose on to these delights.
paragraphs.translated: It makes me very happy to hear he's so interested. Gentlemen, please try to sharpen his interest even more, and let this play do him some good.

paragraphs.original: We shall, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: We will, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.

paragraphs.original:
Sweet Gertrude, leave us too,
For we have closely sent for Hamlet hither,
That he, as 'twere by accident, may here
Affront Ophelia.
Her father and myself (lawful espials)
Will so bestow ourselves that, seeing unseen,
We may of their encounter frankly judge,
And gather by him, as he is behaved,
If 't be the affliction of his love or no
That thus he suffers for.
paragraphs.translated: Dear Gertrude, please give us a moment alone. We've secretly arranged for Hamlet to come here so that he can run into Ophelia. Her father and I, justifiably acting as spies, will hide in the room and observe Hamlet's behavior, to determine whether it's love that's making him suffer.

paragraphs.original:
I shall obey you.
And for your part, Ophelia, I do wish
That your good beauties be the happy cause
Of Hamlet's wildness. So shall I hope your virtues
Will bring him to his wonted way again,
To both your honors.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I'll go. As for you, Ophelia, I hope that your beauty is the reason for Hamlet's insane behavior, just as I hope your virtues will return him to normal some day, for the good of both of you.

paragraphs.original: Madam, I wish it may.
paragraphs.translated: I hope so too, Madam.

paragraphs.original: Exit GERTRUDE
paragraphs.translated: GERTRUDE exits.

paragraphs.original:
Ophelia, walk you here. (to CLAUDIUS) Gracious, so please you,
(to
)
We will bestow ourselves. (to OPHELIA)Read on this book
(to
)
That show of such an exercise may color
Your loneliness. - We are oft to blame in this,
'Tis too much proved, that with devotion's visage
And pious action we do sugar o'er
The devil himself.

(aside) Oh, 'tis too true!
(aside)
How smart a lash that speech doth give my conscience!
The harlot's cheek, beautied with plastering art,
Is not more ugly to the thing that helps it
Than is my deed to my most painted word.
O heavy burden!
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) How right he is! His words whip up my guilty feelings. The whore's pockmarked cheek made pretty with make-up is just like the ugly actions I'm disguising with fine words. What a terrible guilt I feel!
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: I hear him coming. Let's withdraw, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I hear him coming. Quick, let's hide, my lord.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIUS and POLONIUS withdraw
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS and POLONIUS hide.

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET enters.

paragraphs.original:
To be, or not to be? That is the question - 
Whether 'tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune,
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,
And, by opposing, end them? To die, to sleep - 
No more - and by a sleep to say we end
The heartache and the thousand natural shocks
That flesh is heir to - 'tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wished! To die, to sleep.
To sleep, perchance to dream - ay, there's the rub,
For in that sleep of death what dreams may come
When we have shuffled off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause. There's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life.
paragraphs.translated: The question is: is it better to be alive or dead? Is it nobler to put up with all the nasty things that luck throws your way, or to fight against all those troubles by simply putting an end to them once and for all? Dying, sleeping - that's all dying is - a sleep that ends all the heartache and shocks that life on earth gives us - that's an achievement to wish for. To die, to sleep - to sleep, maybe to dream. Ah, but there's the catch: in death's sleep who knows what kind of dreams might come, after we've put the noise and commotion of life behind us. That's certainly something to worry about. That's the consideration that makes us stretch out our sufferings so long.

paragraphs.original:
For who would bear the whips and scorns of time,
Th' oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely,
The pangs of despised love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That patient merit of th' unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear,
To grunt and sweat under a weary life,
But that the dread of something after death,
The undiscovered country from whose bourn
No traveler returns, puzzles the will
And makes us rather bear those ills we have
Than fly to others that we know not of?
Thus conscience does make cowards of us all,
And thus the native hue of resolution
Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought,
And enterprises of great pith and moment
With this regard their currents turn awry,
And lose the name of action. - Soft you now,
The fair Ophelia! - Nymph, in thy orisons
Be all my sins remembered.
paragraphs.translated:
After all, who would put up with all life's humiliations - the abuse from superiors, the insults of arrogant men, the pangs of unrequited love, the inefficiency of the legal system, the rudeness of people in office, and the mistreatment good people have to take from bad - when you could simply take out your knife and call it quits? Who would choose to grunt and sweat through an exhausting life, unless they were afraid of something dreadful after death, the undiscovered country from which no visitor returns, which we wonder about without getting any answers from and which makes us stick to the evils we know rather than rush off to seek the ones we don't? Fear of death makes us all cowards, and our natural boldness becomes weak with too much thinking. Actions that should be carried out at once get misdirected, and stop being actions at all. But shh, here comes the beautiful Ophelia. Pretty lady, please remember me when you pray.
shh

paragraphs.original:
Good my lord,
How does your honor for this many a day?
paragraphs.translated: Hello, my lord, how have you been doing lately?

paragraphs.original: I humbly thank you. Well, well, well.
paragraphs.translated: Very well, thank you. Well, well, well.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, I have remembrances of yours
That I have longèd long to redeliver.
I pray you now receive them.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I have some mementos of yours that I've been meaning to give back to you for a long time now. Please take them.

paragraphs.original: No, not I. I never gave you aught.
paragraphs.translated: No, it wasn't me. I never gave you anything.

paragraphs.original:
My honored lord, you know right well you did,
And with them, words of so sweet breath composed
As made the things more rich. Their perfume lost,
paragraphs.translated: My lord, you know very well that you did, and wrote letters to go along with them, letters so sweetly written that they made your gifts even more valuable. Their perfume is gone now, so take them back. Nice gifts lose

paragraphs.original:
Take these again, for to the noble mind
Rich gifts wax poor when givers prove unkind.
There, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: their value when the givers turn out not to be so nice. There, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Ha, ha, are you honest?
paragraphs.translated: Ha ha, are you good?

paragraphs.original: My lord?
paragraphs.translated: Excuse me?

paragraphs.original: Are you fair?
paragraphs.translated: Are you beautiful?

paragraphs.original: What means your lordship?
paragraphs.translated: My lord, what are you talking about?

paragraphs.original: That if you be honest and fair, your honesty should admit no discourse to your beauty.
paragraphs.translated: I'm just saying that if you're good and beautiful, your goodness should have nothing to do with your beauty.

paragraphs.original: Could beauty, my lord, have better commerce than with honesty?
paragraphs.translated: But could beauty be related to anything better than goodness?

paragraphs.original: Ay, truly, for the power of beauty will sooner transform honesty from what it is to a bawd than the force of honesty can translate beauty into his likeness. This was sometime a paradox, but now the time gives it proof. I did love you once.
paragraphs.translated: Sure, since beauty's power can more easily change a good girl into a whore than the power of goodness can change a beautiful girl into a virgin. This used to be a great puzzle, but now I've solved it. I used to love you.

paragraphs.original: Indeed, my lord, you made me believe so.
paragraphs.translated: You certainly made me believe you did, my lord.

paragraphs.original: You should not have believed me, for virtue cannot so inoculate our old stock but we shall relish of it. I loved you not.
paragraphs.translated: You shouldn't have believed me, since we're all rotten at the core, no matter how hard we try to be virtuous. I didn't love you.

paragraphs.original: I was the more deceived.
paragraphs.translated: Then I guess I was misled.

paragraphs.original: Get thee to a nunnery. Why wouldst thou be a breeder of sinners? I am myself indifferent honest, but yet I could accuse me of such things that it were better my mother had not borne me.
paragraphs.translated:
Get yourself to a
convent at once. Why would you want to give birth to more sinners? I'm fairly good myself, but even so I could accuse myself of such horrible crimes that it would've been better if my mother had never given birth to me. and
convent

paragraphs.original: I am very proud, revengeful, ambitious, with more offences at my beck than I have thoughts to put them in, imagination to give them shape, or time to act them in. What should such fellows as I do crawling between earth and heaven? We are arrant knaves, all. Believe none of us. Go thy ways to a nunnery. Where's your father?
paragraphs.translated: I am arrogant, vengeful, ambitious, with more ill will in me than I can fit into my thoughts, and more than I have time to carry it out in. Why should people like me be crawling around between earth and heaven? Every one of us is a criminal. Don't believe any of us. Hurry to a convent. Where's your father?

paragraphs.original: At home, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: He's at home, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Let the doors be shut upon him, that he may play the fool no where but in 's own house. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: Lock him in, so he can play the fool in his own home only. Good-bye.

paragraphs.original: O, help him, you sweet heavens!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, dear God, please help him!

paragraphs.original: If thou dost marry, I'll give thee this plague for thy dowry. Be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow, thou shalt not escape calumny. Get thee to a nunnery, go. Farewell. Or, if thou wilt needs marry, marry a fool, for wise men know well enough what monsters you make of them. To a nunnery, go, and quickly too. Farewell.
paragraphs.translated: If you marry, I'll give you this curse as your wedding present - be as clean as ice, as pure as the driven snow, and you'll still get a bad reputation. Get yourself to a convent, at once. Good-bye. Or if you have to get married, marry a fool, since wise men know far too well that you'll cheat on them. Good-bye.

paragraphs.original: Heavenly powers, restore him!
paragraphs.translated: Dear God, please make him normal again!

paragraphs.original: I have heard of your paintings too, well enough. God has given you one face and you make yourselves another. You jig and amble, and you lisp, you nickname God's creatures and make your wantonness your ignorance. Go to, I'll no more on 't. It hath made me mad. I say, we will have no more marriages. Those that are married already, all but one, shall live. The rest shall keep as they are. To a nunnery, go.
paragraphs.translated: I've heard all about you women and your cosmetics too. God gives you one face, but you paint another on top of it. You dance and prance and lisp; you call God's creations by pet names, and you excuse your sexpot ploys by pleading ignorance. Come on, I won't stand for it anymore. It's driven me crazy. I hereby declare we will have no more marriage. Whoever is already married (except one person I know) will stay married - all but one person. Everyone else will have to stay single. Get yourself to a convent, fast.

paragraphs.original: Exit HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET exits.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, what a noble mind is here o'erthrown! - 
The courtier's, soldier's, scholar's, eye, tongue, sword,
Th' expectancy and rose of the fair state,
The glass of fashion and the mould of form,
Th' observed of all observers, quite, quite down!
And I, of ladies most deject and wretched,
That sucked the honey of his music vows,
Now see that noble and most sovereign reason
Like sweet bells jangled, out of tune and harsh;
That unmatched form and feature of blown youth
Blasted with ecstasy. Oh, woe is me,
T' have seen what I have seen, see what I see!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, how noble his mind used to be, and how lost he is now! He used to have a gentleman's grace, a scholar's wit, and a soldier's strength. He used to be the jewel of our country, the obvious heir to the throne, the one everyone admired and imitated. And now he has fallen so low! And of all the miserable women who once enjoyed hearing his sweet, seductive words, I am the most miserable. A mind that used to sing so sweetly is now completely out of tune, making harsh sounds instead of fine notes. The unparalleled appearance and nobility he had in the full bloom of his youth has been ruined by madness. O, how miserable I am to see Hamlet now and know what he was before!

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIUS and POLONIUS come forward
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS and POLONIUS come forward.

paragraphs.original:
Love? His affections do not that way tend.
Nor what he spake, though it lacked form a little,
Was not like madness. There's something in his soul
O'er which his melancholy sits on brood,
And I do doubt the hatch and the disclose
Will be some danger - which for to prevent,
I have in quick determination
Thus set it down: he shall with speed to England
For the demand of our neglected tribute.
Haply the seas and countries different
With variable objects shall expel
This something-settled matter in his heart,
Whereon his brains still beating puts him thus
From fashion of himself. What think you on 't?
paragraphs.translated: Love? His feelings don't move in that direction. And his words, although they were a little disorganized, weren't crazy. No, his sadness is hatching something, like a hen does sitting on an egg. What hatches very well may be dangerous. So to prevent any harm being done, I've made a quick executive decision: he'll be sent to England to try to get back the money they owe us. With any luck, the sea and new countries will push out these thoughts that have somehow taken root in his mind. What do you think of this plan?

paragraphs.original:
It shall do well. But yet do I believe
The origin and commencement of his grief
Sprung from neglected love. - How now, Ophelia?
You need not tell us what Lord Hamlet said.
paragraphs.translated: It should work. But I still believe that his madness was caused by unrequited love. - Hello, Ophelia. You don't have to tell us what Lord Hamlet said.

paragraphs.original:
We heard it all. - My lord, do as you please.
But, if you hold it fit, after the play
Let his queen mother all alone entreat him
To show his grief. Let her be round with him,
And I'll be placed, so please you, in the ear
Of all their conference. If she find him not,
To England send him or confine him where
Your wisdom best shall think.
paragraphs.translated: We heard everything. - My lord, do whatever you like, but if you like this idea, let his mother the queen get him alone and beg him to share his feelings with her. I'll hide and listen in. If she can't find out what his secret is, then send him off to England or wherever you think best.

paragraphs.original:
It shall be so.
Madness in great ones must not unwatched go.
paragraphs.translated: That's how we'll do it, then. When important people start to show signs of insanity, you have to watch them closely.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They all exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET and PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and the PLAYERS enter.

paragraphs.original: Speak the speech, I pray you, as I pronounced it to you, trippingly on the tongue. But if you mouth it, as many of your players do, I had as lief the town crier spoke my lines. Nor do not saw the air too much with your hand thus, but use all gently, for in the very torrent, tempest, and (as I may say) whirlwind of passion, you must acquire and beget a temperance that may give it smoothness. Oh, it offends me to the soul to hear a robustious periwig-pated fellow tear a passion to tatters, to very rags, to split the ears of the groundlings, who for the most part are capable of nothing but inexplicable dumb-shows and noise. I would have such a fellow whipped for o'erdoing Termagant. It out-Herods Herod. Pray you, avoid it.
paragraphs.translated: Perform the speech just as I taught you, musically and smoothly. If you exaggerate the words the way some actors do, I might as well have some newscaster read the lines. Don't use too many hand gestures; just do a few, gently, like this. When you get into a whirlwind of passion on stage, remember to keep the emotion moderate and smooth. I hate it when I hear a blustery actor in a wig tear a passion to shreds, bursting everyone's eardrums so as to impress the audience on the lower levels of the playhouse, who for the most part can only appreciate loud noises and pantomime shows. I would whip a guy for making a tyrant sound too tyrannical. That's as bad as those old plays in which King Herod ranted. Please avoid doing that.

paragraphs.original: I warrant your honor.
paragraphs.translated: I will, sir.

paragraphs.original: Be not too tame neither, but let your own discretion be your tutor. Suit the action to the word, the word to the action, with this special observance that you o'erstep not the modesty of nature. For anything so overdone is from the purpose of playing, whose end, both at the first and now, was and is to hold, as 'twere, the mirror up to nature, to show virtue her own feature, scorn her own image, and the very age and body of the time his form and pressure. Now this overdone or come tardy off, though it make the unskillful laugh, cannot but make the judicious grieve, the censure of the which one must in your allowance o'erweigh a whole theatre of others.
paragraphs.translated: But don't be too tame, either - let your good sense guide you. Fit the action to the word and the word to the action. Act natural at all costs. Exaggeration has no place in the theater, where the purpose is to represent reality, holding a mirror up to virtue, to vice, and to the spirit of the times. If you handle this badly, it just makes ignorant people laugh while regular theater-goers are miserable - and they're the ones you should be keeping happy.

paragraphs.original: Oh, there be players that I have seen play and heard others praise (and that highly), not to speak it profanely, that, neither having th' accent of Christians nor the gait of Christian, pagan, nor man, have so strutted and bellowed that I have thought some of nature's journeymen had made men and not made them well, they imitated humanity so abominably.
paragraphs.translated: I've seen actors who are highly praised, but who - not to be too rude here - can't even talk or walk like human beings. They bellow and strut about like weird animals that were made to look like men, but very badly.

paragraphs.original: I hope we have reformed that indifferently with us, sir.
paragraphs.translated: I hope we've corrected that fault pretty well in our company, sir.

paragraphs.original: O, reform it altogether! And let those that play your clowns speak no more than is set down for them, for there be of them that will themselves laugh to set on some quantity of barren spectators to laugh too, though in the meantime some necessary question of the play be then to be considered. That's villainous, and shows a most pitiful ambition in the fool that uses it. Go, make you ready.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, correct it completely. Make sure that the clowns do not ad-lib, since some of them will make certain dumb audience members laugh mindlessly at them, while an important issue in the play needs to be addressed. It's bad behavior for an actor, anyway, and displays a pitiful ambition to hog the limelight on stage.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: The PLAYERS exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS, GUILDENSTERN, and ROSENCRANTZ enter.

paragraphs.original: How now, my lord! Will the king hear this piece of work?
paragraphs.translated: So, my lord, will the king be attending the performance?

paragraphs.original: And the queen too, and that presently.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, he will, and the queen as well.

paragraphs.original: Bid the players make haste.
paragraphs.translated: Tell the actors to hurry.

paragraphs.original: Exit POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: Will you two help to hasten them?
paragraphs.translated: Will you two help them get ready?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.

paragraphs.original: What ho, Horatio!
paragraphs.translated: Well, hello there, Horatio!

paragraphs.original: Enter HORATIO
paragraphs.translated: HORATIO enters.

paragraphs.original: Here, sweet lord, at your service.
paragraphs.translated: Here I am at your service, my dear lord.

paragraphs.original:
Horatio, thou art e'en as just a man
As e'er my conversation coped withal.
paragraphs.translated: Horatio, you're the best man I've ever known.

paragraphs.original: O my dear lord -
paragraphs.translated: Oh, sir -

paragraphs.original:
Nay, do not think I flatter.
For what advancement may I hope from thee
That no revenue hast but thy good spirits,
To feed and clothe thee? Why should the poor be flattered?
No, let the candied tongue lick absurd pomp,
And crook the pregnant hinges of the knee
Where thrift may follow fawning. Dost thou hear?
Since my dear soul was mistress of her choice
And could of men distinguish, her election
Hath sealed thee for herself, for thou hast been - 
As one in suffering all that suffers nothing - 
A man that Fortune's buffets and rewards
Hast ta'en with equal thanks. And blessed are those
Whose blood and judgment are so well commingled,
That they are not a pipe for Fortune's finger
To sound what stop she please. Give me that man
That is not passion's slave, and I will wear him
In my heart's core, ay, in my heart of heart,
As I do thee. - Something too much of this. - 
There is a play tonight before the king.
One scene of it comes near the circumstance
Which I have told thee of my father's death.
I prithee, when thou seest that act afoot,
Even with the very comment of thy soul
Observe mine uncle. If his occulted guilt
Do not itself unkennel in one speech,
It is a damnèd ghost that we have seen,
And my imaginations are as foul
paragraphs.translated: Don't think I'm flattering you. What could I hope to get from you, who've got nothing but your charm to support you in life? Why would anyone flatter a poor person? No, keep flattery for kissing the hands of those who can pay well. You understand? Ever since I've been a free agent in my choice of friends, I've chosen you because you take everything life hands you with calm acceptance, grateful for both good and bad. Blessed are those who mix emotion with reason in just the right proportion, making them strong enough to resist the whims of Lady Luck. Show me the person who's master of his emotions, and I'll put him close to my heart - in my heart of hearts - as I do you. But I'm talking too much. The point is, there's a play being performed for the king tonight. One of the scenes comes very close to depicting the circumstances of my father's death, as I described them to you. Watch my uncle carefully when that scene begins. If his guilty secret does not reveal itself, then that ghost was just a devil, and my hunch wasn't, in fact, worth anything.

paragraphs.original:
As Vulcan's stithy. Give him heedful note.
For I mine eyes will rivet to his face,
And after we will both our judgments join
In censure of his seeming.
paragraphs.translated: Watch him closely. I'll stare at him too, and afterward we'll compare notes on him.

paragraphs.original:
Well, my lord.
If he steal aught the whilst this play is playing,
And 'scape detecting, I will pay the theft.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, I'll watch him as closely as I would a thief. I won't miss a trick.

paragraphs.original:
Danish march. Sound a flourish. Enter King CLAUDIUS, Queen GERTRUDE, POLONIUS, OPHELIA, ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN and other lords attendant with CLAUDIUS's; guard carrying torches

Queen
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play. CLAUDIUS enters with GERTRUDE, POLONIUS, OPHELIA, ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN, and other lords attendant with CLAUDIUS 's guard carrying torches.

paragraphs.original:
They are coming to the play. I must be idle.
Get you a place.
paragraphs.translated: They're coming. I can't talk now. Take your seat.

paragraphs.original: How fares our cousin Hamlet?
paragraphs.translated: So how's my nephew Hamlet doing?

paragraphs.original: Excellent, i' faith, of the chameleon's dish. I eat the air, promise-crammed. You cannot feed capons so.
paragraphs.translated: Wonderful! I eat the air, like chameleons do. I'm positively stuffed with air, I eat so much of it.

paragraphs.original: I have nothing with this answer, Hamlet. These words are not mine.
paragraphs.translated: I have no idea what you're talking about, Hamlet. You're not answering my question.

paragraphs.original: That did I, my lord, and was accounted a good actor.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed I did, my lord. I was considered to be quite a good actor.

paragraphs.original: What did you enact?
paragraphs.translated: What role did you play?

paragraphs.original: I did enact Julius Caesar. I was killed i' th' Capitol. Brutus killed me.
paragraphs.translated: I played Julius Caesar. I was killed in the Capitol. Brutus killed me.

paragraphs.original: It was a brute part of him to kill so capital a calf there. - Be the players ready?
paragraphs.translated: That was brutish of them, to kill so capital a guy.  - Are the actors ready?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord. They stay upon your patience.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord. They're ready whenever you are.

paragraphs.original: Come hither, my dear Hamlet, sit by me.
paragraphs.translated: Come here, my dear Hamlet. Sit by me.

paragraphs.original: Lady, shall I lie in your lap?
paragraphs.translated: My lady, should I lie in your lap?

paragraphs.original: No, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord.

paragraphs.original: I mean, my head upon your lap?
paragraphs.translated: I mean, with my head in your lap?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Do you think I meant country matters?
paragraphs.translated: Did you think I was talking about sex?

paragraphs.original: I think nothing, my lord.
paragraphs.translated:
I think
nothing, my lord.
nothing

paragraphs.original: That's a fair thought to lie between maids' legs.
paragraphs.translated: That's a nice thought to lie between a girl's legs.

paragraphs.original: What is, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What is, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Nothing.
paragraphs.translated: Nothing.

paragraphs.original: You are merry, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: You're in a good mood tonight, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Who, I?
paragraphs.translated: Who, me?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: O God, your only jig-maker. What should a man do but be merry? For, look you, how cheerfully my mother looks, and my father died within these two hours.
paragraphs.translated: Oh God - who is, by the way, the best comic of them all. What can you do but be happy? Look how cheerful my mother is, only two hours after my father died.

paragraphs.original: Nay, 'tis twice two months, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord, it's been four months.

paragraphs.original: So long? Nay then, let the devil wear black, for I'll have a suit of sables. O heavens! Die two months ago and not forgotten yet? Then there's hope a great man's memory may outlive his life half a year. But, by 'r Lady, he must build churches then, or else shall he suffer not thinking on, with the hobby-horse, whose epitaph is "For, oh, for, oh, the hobby-horse is forgot."
paragraphs.translated: As long as that? Well, in that case these mourning clothes can go to hell. I'll get myself a fur-trimmed suit. Good heavens, he died two months ago and hasn't been forgotten yet? In that case, there's reason to hope a man's memory may outlive him by six months. But he's got to build churches for that to happen, my lady, or else he'll have to put up with being forgotten, like the hobby-horse in the popular song that goes, "Heigh-ho, heigh-ho, the hobby-horse is forgotten."

paragraphs.original:
Trumpets sound. The dumb show begins
Trumpets sound. The dumb show begins
Enter a King and a Queen very lovingly, the Queen embracing him and he her. She kneels and makes show of protestation unto him. He takes her up and declines his head upon her neck, lays him down upon a bank of flowers. She, seeing him asleep, leaves him. Anon comes in a fellow, takes off his crown, kisses it, pours poison in the King's ears, and exits. The Queen returns, finds the King dead, and makes passionate action. The Poisoner, with some two or three Mutes, comes in again, seeming to lament with her. The dead body is carried away. The Poisoner woos the Queen with gifts. She seems loath and unwilling awhile, but in the end accepts his love

paragraphs.translated:
Trumpets play. The pantomime show begins. A king and queen enter and embrace lovingly. She kneels before him and resists his passion. He lifts her up and lays his head on her neck. He lies down on a bank of flowers. When she sees him sleeping, she leaves. Another man comes in, takes the crown from the king, pours poison in the sleeping man's ear, and leaves. The queen returns and finds the king dead. She becomes hysterical. The killer comes back with three others and calms the queen. The body is carried away. The killer woos the queen with gifts. She is cold toward him for a while but then relents and accepts his advances.

He lies down on a bank of flowers. When she sees him sleeping, she leaves. Another man comes in, takes the crown from the king, pours poison in the sleeping man's ear, and leaves. The queen returns and finds the king dead. She becomes hysterical. The killer comes back with three others and calms the queen. The body is carried away. The killer woos the queen with gifts. She is cold toward him for a while but then relents and accepts his advances.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt PLAYERS
paragraphs.translated: The PLAYERS exit.

paragraphs.original: What means this, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What does this mean, my lord?

paragraphs.original:
Marry, this is miching malhecho. It means mischief.
malhecho
paragraphs.translated: This means we're having some mischievous fun.

paragraphs.original: Belike this show imports the argument of the play.
paragraphs.translated: This pantomime was probably a summary of the play.

paragraphs.original: Enter PROLOGUE
paragraphs.translated: The PROLOGUE - the actor who will introduce the play - enters.

paragraphs.original: We shall know by this fellow. The players cannot keep counsel. They'll tell all.
paragraphs.translated: This guy will tell us everything. Actors can't keep a secret. They'll tell all.

paragraphs.original: Will he tell us what this show meant?
paragraphs.translated: Will he tell us what that pantomime meant?

paragraphs.original: Ay, or any show that you will show him. Be not you ashamed to show, he'll not shame to tell you what it means.
paragraphs.translated: Sure, or anything else you show him. As long as you aren't ashamed to show it, he won't be ashamed to tell you what it means.

paragraphs.original: You are naught, you are naught. I'll mark the play.
paragraphs.translated: You're naughty. I'm watching the play.

paragraphs.original:
For us and for our tragedy,
For us and for our tragedy
Here stooping to your clemency,
Here stooping to your clemency
We beg your hearing patiently.
We beg your hearing patiently
paragraphs.translated:
We beg you most courteously
We beg you most courteously
To be patient with us
To be patient with us
And watch our humble tragedy.
And watch our humble tragedy

paragraphs.original: Exit PROLOGUE
paragraphs.translated: The PROLOGUE exits.

paragraphs.original: Is this a prologue or the posy of a ring?
paragraphs.translated: Was that the prologue or the inscription on some wedding ring?

paragraphs.original: 'Tis brief, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: It was a bit short, my lord.

paragraphs.original: As woman's love.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, as short as a woman's love.

paragraphs.original: Enter PLAYER KING and PLAYER QUEEN
paragraphs.translated: Actors playing the roles of KING and QUEEN enter.

paragraphs.original:
Full thirty times hath Phoebus' cart gone round
Full thirty times hath Phoebus' cart gone round
Neptune's salt wash and Tellus' orbèd ground,
Neptune's salt wash and Tellus' orbèd ground
And thirty dozen moons with borrowed sheen
And thirty dozen moons with borrowed sheen
About the world have times twelve thirties been,
About the world have times twelve thirties been
Since love our hearts and Hymen did our hands
Since love our hearts and Hymen did our hands
Unite commutual in most sacred bands.
Unite commutual in most sacred bands
paragraphs.translated:
It's been thirty years since we were married.
It's been thirty years since we were married

paragraphs.original:
So many journeys may the sun and moon
So many journeys may the sun and moon
Make us again count o'er ere love be done.
Make us again count o'er ere love be done
But woe is me! You are so sick of late,
But woe is me! You are so sick of late
So far from cheer and from your former state,
So far from cheer and from your former state
That I distrust you. Yet though I distrust,
That I distrust you. Yet though I distrust
Discomfort you, my lord, it nothing must.
Discomfort you, my lord, it nothing must
For women fear too much, even as they love,
For women fear too much, even as they love
And women's fear and love hold quantity,
And women's fear and love hold quantity
In neither aught, or in extremity.
In neither aught, or in extremity
Now what my love is, proof hath made you know,
Now what my love is, proof hath made you know
And as my love is sized, my fear is so:
And as my love is sized, my fear is so
Where love is great, the littlest doubts are fear.
Where love is great, the littlest doubts are fear
Where little fears grow great, great love grows there.
Where little fears grow great, great love grows there
paragraphs.translated:
I hope we stay in love for thirty more years! But I'm sad. You've been so gloomy lately, so unlike your usual cheerful self, that I worry something is wrong. But don't let this upset you, since women are too afraid in love - for them, love and fear go hand in hand. You know very well how much I love you, and my fear is just as deep. When someone's love is great, the little worries become very big. So when you see someone who worries a lot about little things, you know they're really in love.
I hope we stay in love for thirty more years! But I'm sad. You've been so gloomy lately, so unlike your usual cheerful self, that I worry something is wrong. But don't let this upset you, since women are too afraid in love - for them, love and fear go hand in hand. You know very well how much I love you, and my fear is just as deep. When someone's love is great, the little worries become very big. So when you see someone who worries a lot about little things, you know they're really in love

paragraphs.original:
Faith, I must leave thee, love, and shortly too.
Faith, I must leave thee, love, and shortly too
My operant powers their functions leave to do.
My operant powers their functions leave to do
And thou shalt live in this fair world behind,
And thou shalt live in this fair world behind
Honored, beloved, and haply one as kind
Honored, beloved, and haply one as kind
For husband shalt thou - 
For husband shalt thou -
paragraphs.translated:
My love, I will have to leave you soon. My body is growing weak, and I will leave you behind in this beautiful world, honored and much loved. Perhaps you'll find another husband - 
My love, I will have to leave you soon. My body is growing weak, and I will leave you behind in this beautiful world, honored and much loved. Perhaps you'll find another husband

paragraphs.original:
Oh, confound the rest!
Oh, confound the rest
Such love must needs be treason in my breast.
Such love must needs be treason in my breast
In second husband let me be accursed!
In second husband let me be accursed
None wed the second but who killed the first.
None wed the second but who killed the first
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, damn everyone else! Remarrying would be treason to my heart. Curse me if I take a second husband. When a woman takes a second husband, it's because she's killed off the first.
Oh, damn everyone else! Remarrying would be treason to my heart. Curse me if I take a second husband. When a woman takes a second husband, it's because she's killed off the first

paragraphs.original:
(aside)Wormwood, wormwood.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) Harsh!
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
The instances that second marriage move
The instances that second marriage move
Are base respects of thrift, but none of love.
Are base respects of thrift, but none of love
A second time I kill my husband dead
A second time I kill my husband dead
When second husband kisses me in bed.
When second husband kisses me in bed
paragraphs.translated:
Someone might marry a second time for money, but never for love. Any time I kissed my second husband in bed, I'd kill the first one all over again.
Someone might marry a second time for money, but never for love. Any time I kissed my second husband in bed, I'd kill the first one all over again

paragraphs.original:
I do believe you think what now you speak,
I do believe you think what now you speak
But what we do determine oft we break.
But what we do determine oft we break
Purpose is but the slave to memory,
Purpose is but the slave to memory
Of violent birth, but poor validity,
Of violent birth, but poor validity
Which now, like fruit unripe, sticks on the tree,
Which now, like fruit unripe, sticks on the tree
But fall, unshaken, when they mellow be.
But fall, unshaken, when they mellow be
Most necessary 'tis that we forget
Most necessary 'tis that we forget
To pay ourselves what to ourselves is debt.
To pay ourselves what to ourselves is debt
What to ourselves in passion we propose,
What to ourselves in passion we propose
The passion ending, doth the purpose lose.
The passion ending, doth the purpose lose
The violence of either grief or joy
The violence of either grief or joy
Their own enactures with themselves destroy.
Their own enactures with themselves destroy
Where joy most revels, grief doth most lament.
Where joy most revels, grief doth most lament
Grief joys, joy grieves on slender accident.
Grief joys, joy grieves on slender accident
This world is not for aye, nor 'tis not strange
This world is not for aye, nor 'tis not strange
That even our loves should with our fortunes change.
That even our loves should with our fortunes change
For 'tis a question left us yet to prove,
For 'tis a question left us yet to prove
Whether love lead fortune, or else fortune love.
Whether love lead fortune, or else fortune love
The great man down, you mark his favorite flies.
The great man down, you mark his favorite flies
The poor advanced makes friends of enemies.
The poor advanced makes friends of enemies
And hitherto doth love on fortune tend,
And hitherto doth love on fortune tend
For who not needs shall never lack a friend,
For who not needs shall never lack a friend
And who in want a hollow friend doth try,
And who in want a hollow friend doth try
Directly seasons him his enemy.
Directly seasons him his enemy
But, orderly to end where I begun,
But, orderly to end where I begun
Our wills and fates do so contrary run
Our wills and fates do so contrary run
That our devices still are overthrown.
That our devices still are overthrown
Our thoughts are ours, their ends none of our own.
Our thoughts are ours, their ends none of our own
So think thou wilt no second husband wed,
So think thou wilt no second husband wed
But die thy thoughts when thy first lord is dead.
But die thy thoughts when thy first lord is dead
paragraphs.translated:
I know that's what you think now, but people change their minds. Often our intentions are strong at first, but as time goes on they weaken, just like an apple sticks to the tree when it is unripe but falls to the ground once it ripens. The promises we make to ourselves in emotional moments lose their power once the emotion passes. Great grief and joy may rouse us to action, but when the grief or joy have passed, we're no longer motivated to act. Joy turns to grief in the blink of an eye, and grief becomes joy just as quickly. This world is not made for either one to last long in, and it's no surprise that even our loves change along with our luck. It's still a mystery to be solved whether luck controls love, or love controls luck. When a great man has a run of bad luck, watch how followers desert him, and when a poor man advances to an important position, he makes friends with the people he used to hate. Love is unreliable. A person with lots of money will always have friends, while one fallen on hard times makes an enemy of any friend he turns to for money. But back to my original point - what we want and what we get are always at odds. We can have our little dreams, but the fates decide our futures. You think now you'll never remarry, but that thought will die with me, your first husband.

paragraphs.original:
Nor earth to me give food, nor heaven light.
Nor earth to me give food, nor heaven light
Sport and repose lock from me day and night.
Sport and repose lock from me day and night
To desperation turn my trust and hope.
To desperation turn my trust and hope
An anchor's cheer in prison be my scope.
An anchor's cheer in prison be my scope
Each opposite that blanks the face of joy
Each opposite that blanks the face of joy
Meet what I would have well and it destroy.
Meet what I would have well and it destroy
Both here and hence pursue me lasting strife
Both here and hence pursue me lasting strife
If, once a widow, ever I be wife!
If, once a widow, ever I be wife
paragraphs.translated:
May the earth refuse me food and the heavens go dark, may I have no rest day and night, may my trust and hope turn to despair - may the gloom of a prison overtake me, and may my every joy be turned to sorrow.
May the earth refuse me food and the heavens go dark, may I have no rest day and night, may my trust and hope turn to despair - may the gloom of a prison overtake me, and may my every joy be turned to sorrow
May I know no peace either in this life or the next one, if I become a wife again after I am a widow.
May I know no peace either in this life or the next one, if I become a wife again after I am a widow

paragraphs.original: If she should break it now!
paragraphs.translated: Nice vow, but what if she breaks it?

paragraphs.original:
'Tis deeply sworn. Sweet, leave me here awhile.
'Tis deeply sworn. Sweet, leave me here awhile
My spirits grow dull, and fain I would beguile
My spirits grow dull, and fain I would beguile
The tedious day with sleep.
The tedious day with sleep
paragraphs.translated:
You have made this vow with deep sincerity. My dear, leave me alone now awhile. My mind is getting foggy, and I would like to sleep and escape this endless day.
You have made this vow with deep sincerity. My dear, leave me alone now awhile. My mind is getting foggy, and I would like to sleep and escape this endless day

paragraphs.original: The PLAYER KING sleeps
paragraphs.translated: The PLAYER KING sleeps.

paragraphs.original:
Sleep rock thy brain,
Sleep rock thy brain
And never come mischance between us twain.
And never come mischance between us twain
paragraphs.translated:
Sleep tight, and may nothing come between us.
Sleep tight, and may nothing come between us

paragraphs.original: Exit PLAYER QUEEN
paragraphs.translated: The PLAYER QUEEN exits.

paragraphs.original: Madam, how like you this play?
paragraphs.translated: Madam, how are you liking this play?

paragraphs.original: The lady protests too much, methinks.
paragraphs.translated: The lady's overdoing it, I think.

paragraphs.original: Oh, but she'll keep her word.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, but she'll keep her word.

paragraphs.original: Have you heard the argument? Is there no offense in 't?
paragraphs.translated: Do you know the plot? Is there anything offensive in it?

paragraphs.original: No, no, they do but jest. Poison in jest. No offense i' th' world.
paragraphs.translated: No, no, it's just a joke, a little jibe but all in good fun. Not offensive at all.

paragraphs.original: What do you call the play?
paragraphs.translated: What's the play called?

paragraphs.original:
The Mousetrap. Marry, how? Tropically. This play is the image of a murder done in Vienna. Gonzago is the duke's name, his wife Baptista. You shall see anon. 'Tis a knavish piece of work, but what o' that? Your majesty and we that have free souls, it touches us not. Let the galled jade wince, our withers are unwrung.
The Mousetrap
paragraphs.translated:
The Mousetrap. Why on earth is it called that, you ask? It's a metaphor. This play is about a murder committed in Vienna. Gonzago is the duke's name, and his wife is Baptista. You'll see soon enough. It's a piece of garbage, but who cares? You and I have free souls, so it doesn't concern us. Let the guilty wince. We can watch without being bothered.
The Mousetrap

paragraphs.original: Enter LUCIANUS
paragraphs.translated: LUCIANUS enters.

paragraphs.original: This is one Lucianus, nephew to the king.
paragraphs.translated: This is Lucianus, the king's nephew in the play.

paragraphs.original: You are as good as a chorus, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: You're an expert commentator, aren't you?

paragraphs.original: I could interpret between you and your love, if I could see the puppets dallying.
paragraphs.translated: Yes. I could even supply the dialogue between you and your lover if you did your little puppet show of love for me.

paragraphs.original: You are keen, my lord, you are keen.
paragraphs.translated: Ooh, you're sharp.

paragraphs.original: It would cost you a groaning to take off mine edge.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, pointy, but you could take the edge off me -  though it might make you moan a little.

paragraphs.original: Still better and worse.
paragraphs.translated: You get better in your jokes and worse in your manners.

paragraphs.original: So you must take your husbands. - Begin, murderer. Pox, leave thy damnable faces, and begin. Come, "The croaking raven doth bellow for revenge - "
paragraphs.translated: That's what you women get when you trick us into marriage. - Let's get started, murderer on stage, please! Damn it, stop fussing with the makeup, and get going. We're all waiting for the revenge!

paragraphs.original:
Thoughts black, hands apt, drugs fit, and time agreeing,
Thoughts black, hands apt, drugs fit, and time agreeing
Confederate season, else no creature seeing,
Confederate season, else no creature seeing
Thou mixture rank, of midnight weeds collected,
Thou mixture rank, of midnight weeds collected
With Hecate's ban thrice blasted, thrice infected,
With Hecate's ban thrice blasted, thrice infected
Thy natural magic and dire property
Thy natural magic and dire property
On wholesome life usurp immediately.
On wholesome life usurp immediately
(pours poison into PLAYER KING 's ears)
(pours poison into
's ears)
paragraphs.translated:
Evil thoughts, ready hands, the right poison, and the time is right too. The dark night is on my side, for no one can see me. You deadly mixture of weeds and plants, which Hecate, goddess of witchcraft, has put a spell on, use your magic to steal this healthy person's life away. (pours the poison into the PLAYER KING 's ears)
Evil thoughts, ready hands, the right poison, and the time is right too. The dark night is on my side, for no one can see me. You deadly mixture of weeds and plants, which Hecate, goddess of witchcraft, has put a spell on, use your magic to steal this healthy person's life away. (pours the poison into the
's ears)

paragraphs.original: He poisons him i' th' garden for 's estate. His name's Gonzago. The story is extant, and writ in choice Italian. You shall see anon how the murderer gets the love of Gonzago's wife.
paragraphs.translated: You see, he poisons the king in his own garden to get the kingdom for himself. The king's name is Gonzago. The original story was written in the finest Italian. You'll see shortly how the murderer wins the love of Gonzago's wife.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIUS stands up
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS stands up.

paragraphs.original: The king rises.
paragraphs.translated: The king is getting up.

paragraphs.original: What, frighted with false fire?
paragraphs.translated: What - is he scared of a gun that only fired a blank?

paragraphs.original: How fares my lord?
paragraphs.translated: My lord, how are you feeling?

paragraphs.original: Give o'er the play.
paragraphs.translated: Stop the play.

paragraphs.original: Give me some light, away!
paragraphs.translated: Turn on the lights. Get me out of here!

paragraphs.original: Lights, lights, lights!
paragraphs.translated: Lights, lights, get us some lights!

paragraphs.original: Commotion. Exeunt all but HAMLET and HORATIO
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except HAMLET and HORATIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
Why, let the stricken deer go weep,
Why, let the stricken deer go weep
The hart ungallèd play.
The hart ungallèd play
For some must watch while some must sleep.
For some must watch while some must sleep
So runs the world away.
So runs the world away
Would not this, sir, and a forest of feathers - if the rest of my fortunes turn Turk with me - with two Provincial roses on my razed shoes, get me a fellowship in a cry of players?
paragraphs.translated:
Let the deer that's been shot go off and weep,
Let the deer that's been shot go off and weep
While the unharmed deer happily plays.
While the unharmed deer happily plays
For some must watch while other must sleep,
For some must watch while other must sleep
That's how the world goes.
That's how the world goes
Couldn't I get work as an actor (if I hit a run of bad luck) in some acting company, and wear flowers on my shoes?

paragraphs.original: Half a share.
paragraphs.translated: They might even give you half a share of the company.

paragraphs.original:
A whole one, I.
For thou dost know, O Damon dear,
For thou dost know, O Damon dear
This realm dismantled was
This realm dismantled was
Of Jove himself. And now reigns here
Of Jove himself. And now reigns here
A very, very - pajock.
A very, very - pajock
paragraphs.translated:
No, a whole share for me.
For you know, my dearest Damon,
For you know, my dearest Damon
That Jove, king of the gods, was
That Jove, king of the gods, was
Thrown out of power here, and
Thrown out of power here, and
Who's in charge? A big - peacock.
Who's in charge? A big - peacock

paragraphs.original: You might have rhymed.
paragraphs.translated:
You could have at least
rhymed.
rhymed

paragraphs.original: O good Horatio, I'll take the ghost's word for a thousand pound. Didst perceive?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, Horatio, I'll bet you a thousand bucks the ghost was right. Did you notice?

paragraphs.original: Very well, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, I did, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Upon the talk of the poisoning?
paragraphs.translated: When the actors were talking about poison?

paragraphs.original: I did very well note him.
paragraphs.translated: I watched him very closely.

paragraphs.original:
Ah ha! Come, some music! Come, the recorders!
For if the king like not the comedy,
For if the king like not the comedy
Why then, belike, he likes it not, perdy.
Why then, belike, he likes it not, perdy
Come, some music!
paragraphs.translated:
Ah ha! Hey, let's have some music here! Play your flutes!
For if the king doesn't like the play,
For if the king doesn't like the play
Then he doesn't like it, we may say.
Then he doesn't like it, we may say
Come on, music!

paragraphs.original: Enter ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN enter.

paragraphs.original: Good my lord, vouchsafe me a word with you.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, could I have a word with you?

paragraphs.original: Sir, a whole history.
paragraphs.translated: You can have a whole story, not just a word.

paragraphs.original: The king, sir -
paragraphs.translated: Sir, the king -

paragraphs.original: Ay, sir, what of him?
paragraphs.translated: Yes, what about him?

paragraphs.original: Is in his retirement marvelous distempered.
paragraphs.translated: He's in his chambers now, and he's extremely upset.

paragraphs.original: With drink, sir?
paragraphs.translated: What, an upset stomach from too much booze?

paragraphs.original: No, my lord, with choler.
paragraphs.translated: No, sir, he's angry.

paragraphs.original: Your wisdom should show itself more richer to signify this to the doctor. For, for me to put him to his purgation would perhaps plunge him into far more choler.
paragraphs.translated: You should be smart enough to tell this to a doctor, not me, since if I treated him, he'd just get angrier.

paragraphs.original: Good my lord, put your discourse into some frame and start not so wildly from my affair.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, please try to stick to the subject at hand.

paragraphs.original: I am tame, sir. Pronounce.
paragraphs.translated: I'll be good, sir. Go ahead.

paragraphs.original: The queen your mother, in most great affliction of spirit, hath sent me to you.
paragraphs.translated: The queen your mother is upset, and sent me to see you.

paragraphs.original: You are welcome.
paragraphs.translated: It's lovely to see you.

paragraphs.original: Nay, good my lord, this courtesy is not of the right breed. If it shall please you to make me a wholesome answer, I will do your mother's commandment. If not, your pardon and my return shall be the end of my business.
paragraphs.translated: No, my lord, your polite words are not to the point. If you could please stop fooling around, I'll tell you what your mother wants. If not, I'll leave you alone and that'll be the end of my business.

paragraphs.original: Sir, I cannot.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I can't.

paragraphs.original: What, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Can't what, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Make you a wholesome answer. My wit's diseased. But, sir, such answer as I can make, you shall command. Or, rather, as you say, my mother. Therefore no more but to the matter. My mother, you say -
paragraphs.translated: Stop fooling around. My mind is confused. But I'll do my best to give you a straight answer, as you wish - or rather, as my mother wishes. Okay, to the point. My mother, you say …?

paragraphs.original: Then thus she says: your behavior hath struck her into amazement and admiration.
paragraphs.translated: She says that your behavior has astonished her.

paragraphs.original: O wonderful son that can so 'stonish a mother! But is there no sequel at the heels of this mother's admiration? Impart.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a wonderful son, I can impress my mother! But what's the upshot of her admiration? Do tell.

paragraphs.original: She desires to speak with you in her closet ere you go to bed.
paragraphs.translated: She wants to have a word with you in her bedroom before you go to bed.

paragraphs.original: We shall obey, were she ten times our mother. Have you any further trade with us?
paragraphs.translated: I'd obey even if she were my mother ten times over. Is there anything else I can do for you?

paragraphs.original: My lord, you once did love me.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, you used to like me.

paragraphs.original: And do still, by these pickers and stealers.
paragraphs.translated: And still do, I swear by my hands.

paragraphs.original: Good my lord, what is your cause of distemper? You do surely bar the door upon your own liberty if you deny your griefs to your friend.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, what's wrong with you? You're not doing yourself any good by refusing to tell your friends what's bothering you.

paragraphs.original: Sir, I lack advancement.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I have no future ahead of me.

paragraphs.original: How can that be, when you have the voice of the king himself for your succession in Denmark?
paragraphs.translated: But how can you say that, when the king himself says you're the heir to the Danish throne?

paragraphs.original: Reenter the PLAYERS with recorders
paragraphs.translated:
The PLAYERS enter with
recorders .

recorders

paragraphs.original:
Ay, sir, but "While the grass grows - " The proverb is something musty - Oh, the recorders! Let me see one. (takes a recorder) (aside to ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN ) To withdraw with you, why do you go about to recover the wind of me as if you would drive me into a toil?
(takes a recorder)
(aside to
and
)
paragraphs.translated:
Yes, eventually, but as the proverb goes,
"While the grass grows …" But that's a tired old proverb. Oh, the recorders! Let me see one.(he takes a recorder and turns to GUILDENSTERN ) Why are you hovering so close, as if you want to ambush me?
"While the grass grows …"



(he takes a recorder and turns to
)

paragraphs.original: O my lord, if my duty be too bold, my love is too unmannerly.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my lord, I'm sorry if I'm forgetting my manners. It's just that I'm worried about you.

paragraphs.original: I do not well understand that. Will you play upon this pipe?
paragraphs.translated: I don't really understand what you mean. Will you play this recorder?

paragraphs.original: My lord, I cannot.
paragraphs.translated: I can't, my lord.

paragraphs.original: I pray you.
paragraphs.translated: Please.

paragraphs.original: Believe me, I cannot.
paragraphs.translated: I'm serious, I can't.

paragraphs.original: I do beseech you.
paragraphs.translated: I'm begging you.

paragraphs.original: I know no touch of it, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: I have no idea how.

paragraphs.original: It is as easy as lying. Govern these ventages with your fingers and thumb, give it breath with your mouth, and it will discourse most eloquent music. Look you, these are the stops.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, it's as easy as lying. Just put your fingers and thumb over the holes and blow into it, and it'll produce the most moving music. Here, the holes are here.

paragraphs.original:
But these cannot I command to any utterance of harmony.
I have not the skill.
paragraphs.translated: But I can't play a melody. I don't know how.

paragraphs.original: Why, look you now, how unworthy a thing you make of me! You would play upon me. You would seem to know my stops. You would pluck out the heart of my mystery. You would sound me from my lowest note to the top of my compass. And there is much music, excellent voice, in this little organ, yet cannot you make it speak? 'Sblood, do you think I am easier to be played on than a pipe? Call me what instrument you will, though you can fret me, yet you cannot play upon me.
paragraphs.translated: Well, look how you play me - as if you knew exactly where to put your fingers, to blow the mystery out of me, playing all the octaves of my range - and yet you can't even produce music from this little instrument? My God, do you think I'm easier to manipulate than a pipe? You can push my buttons, but you can't play me for a fool.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS enters.

paragraphs.original: God bless you, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Hello and God bless you, sir.

paragraphs.original: My lord, the queen would speak with you, and presently.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, the queen wants to speak with you right away.

paragraphs.original: Do you see yonder cloud that's almost in shape of a camel?
paragraphs.translated: Do you see that cloud up there that looks like a camel?

paragraphs.original: By th' mass, and 'tis like a camel indeed.
paragraphs.translated: By God, it does look like a camel.

paragraphs.original: Methinks it is like a weasel.
paragraphs.translated: To me it looks like a weasel.

paragraphs.original: It is backed like a weasel.
paragraphs.translated: It does have a back like a weasel's.

paragraphs.original: Or like a whale.
paragraphs.translated: Or like a whale.

paragraphs.original: Very like a whale.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, very much like a whale.

paragraphs.original:
Then I will come to my mother by and by. (aside) They fool me to the top of my bent. - I will come by and by.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
I'll go see my mother soon. (to himself) They're trying as hard as they can to mess with me. - I will go soon.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: I will say so.
paragraphs.translated: I'll tell her.

paragraphs.original: "By and by" is easily said.
paragraphs.translated: It's easy enough to say "soon."

paragraphs.original: Exit POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: Leave me, friends.
paragraphs.translated: Now please leave me alone, my friends.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt all but HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: Everyone except HAMLET exits.

paragraphs.original:
'Tis now the very witching time of night,
When churchyards yawn and hell itself breathes out
Contagion to this world. Now could I drink hot blood
And do such bitter business as the bitter day
Would quake to look on. Soft, now to my mother. - 
O heart, lose not thy nature, let not ever
The soul of Nero enter this firm bosom.
Let me be cruel, not unnatural.
paragraphs.translated:
This is the time of night when witches come out, when graveyards yawn open and the stench of hell seeps out. I could drink hot blood and do such terrible deeds that people would tremble even in the daylight. But I've got to go see my mother. - Oh, heart, don't grow weak, like
Nero Let me be cruel, but not inhuman.
Nero

paragraphs.original:
I will speak daggers to her but use none.
My tongue and soul in this be hypocrites.
How in my words somever she be shent,
To give them seals never, my soul, consent!
paragraphs.translated: I'll speak as sharp as a dagger to her, but I won't use one on her. And so, my words and thoughts will be at odds.

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter CLAUDIUS, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS, ROSENCRANTZ, and GUILDENSTERN enter.

paragraphs.original:
I like him not, nor stands it safe with us
To let his madness range. Therefore prepare you.
I your commission will forthwith dispatch,
And he to England shall along with you.
The terms of our estate may not endure
Hazard so dangerous as doth hourly grow
Out of his lunacies.
paragraphs.translated: I don't like the way he's acting, and it's not safe for me to let his insanity get out of control. So get prepared. I'm sending you to England on diplomatic business, and Hamlet will go with you. As king, I cannot risk the danger he represents as he grows crazier by the hour.

paragraphs.original:
We will ourselves provide.
Most holy and religious fear it is
To keep those many, many bodies safe
That live and feed upon your majesty.
paragraphs.translated: We'll take care of it. It's a sacred duty to protect the lives of all those who depend on Your Highness.

paragraphs.original:
The single and peculiar life is bound
With all the strength and armor of the mind
To keep itself from noyance, but much more
That spirit upon whose weal depend and rest
The lives of many. The cease of majesty
Dies not alone, but, like a gulf, doth draw
What's near it with it. It is a massy wheel
Fixed on the summit of the highest mount,
To whose huge spokes ten thousand lesser things
Are mortised and adjoined, which, when it falls,
Each small annexment, petty consequence,
Attends the boisterous ruin. Never alone
Did the king sigh, but with a general groan.
paragraphs.translated: Everyone tries to avoid harm, but the public figure demands even more protection. When a great leader dies he doesn't die alone but, like a whirlpool, draws others with him. He's like a huge wheel on the top of the highest mountain whose spokes touch the rim of ten thousand smaller things - when it falls down the mountain, every little object goes down with it. Whenever a king sighs, everyone groans.

paragraphs.original:
Arm you, I pray you, to this speedy voyage.
For we will fetters put upon this fear,
Which now goes too free-footed.
paragraphs.translated: Prepare yourself, please, for this trip. We'll put a leash on this danger that's now running wild.

paragraphs.original:
ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN
We will haste us.
paragraphs.translated:
ROSENCRANTZ, GUILDENSTERN
We'll hurry.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN
paragraphs.translated: ROSENCRANTZ and GUILDENSTERN exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS enters.

paragraphs.original:
My lord, he's going to his mother's closet.
Behind the arras I'll convey myself
To hear the process. I'll warrant she'll tax him home.
And, as you said (and wisely was it said)
'Tis meet that some more audience than a mother - 
Since nature makes them partial - should o'erhear
The speech, of vantage. Fare you well, my liege.
I'll call upon you ere you go to bed
And tell you what I know.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, Hamlet's going to his mother's room. I'll hide behind the tapestry to hear what they say. I bet she'll chew him out. And as you said (and you said it wisely), it's good to have someone other than a mother listening in on them, since she can be too partial to him. Goodbye, my lord. I'll stop by before you go to bed, and tell you what I've heard.

paragraphs.original: Thanks, dear my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Thanks, my dear lord.

paragraphs.original: Exit POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS exits.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, my offence is rank. It smells to heaven.
It hath the primal eldest curse upon 't,
A brother's murder. Pray can I not.
Though inclination be as sharp as will,
My stronger guilt defeats my strong intent,
And, like a man to double business bound,
I stand in pause where I shall first begin,
And both neglect. What if this cursèd hand
Were thicker than itself with brother's blood?
Is there not rain enough in the sweet heavens
To wash it white as snow? Whereto serves mercy
But to confront the visage of offence?
And what's in prayer but this twofold force,
To be forestallèd ere we come to fall
Or pardoned being down? Then I'll look up.
My fault is past. But oh, what form of prayer
Can serve my turn, "Forgive me my foul murder"?
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, my crime is so rotten it stinks all the way to heaven. It has the mark of
Cain on it, a brother's murder. I can't pray, though I want to desperately. My guilt is stronger even than my intentions. And like a person with two opposite things to do at once, I stand paralyzed and neglect them both. So what if this cursed hand of mine is coated with my brother's blood? Isn't there enough rain in heaven to wash it clean as snow? Isn't that what God's mercy is for? And doesn't prayer serve these two purposes - to keep us from sinning and to bring us forgiveness when we have sinned? So I'll pray. I've already committed my sin. But, oh, what kind of prayer is there for me? "Dear Lord, forgive me for my horrible murder"?
Cain

paragraphs.original:
That cannot be, since I am still possessed
Of those effects for which I did the murder:
My crown, mine own ambition, and my queen.
May one be pardoned and retain th' offense?
In the corrupted currents of this world
Offense's gilded hand may shove by justice,
And oft 'tis seen the wicked prize itself
Buys out the law. But 'tis not so above.
There is no shuffling. There the action lies
In his true nature, and we ourselves compelled,
Even to the teeth and forehead of our faults,
To give in evidence. What then? What rests?
Try what repentance can. What can it not?
Yet what can it when one can not repent?
O wretched state! O bosom black as death!
O limèd soul that, struggling to be free,
Art more engaged! Help, angels. Make assay.
Bow, stubborn knees, and, heart with strings of steel,
Be soft as sinews of the newborn babe.
All may be well. (kneels)
(kneels)
paragraphs.translated:
That won't work, since I'm still reaping the rewards of that murder: my crown and my queen. Can a person be forgiven and still keep the fruits of his crime? In this wicked world, criminals often take the money they stole and use it to buy off the law, shoving justice aside. But not in heaven. Up there, every action is judged for exactly what it's worth, and we're forced to confront our crimes. So what can I do? What is there left to do? Offer whatever repentance I can - that couldn't hurt. But it can't help either! Oh, what a lousy situation I'm in. My heart's as black as death. My soul is stuck to sin, and the more it struggles to break free, the more it sticks. Help me, angels! C'mon, make an effort. Bend, stubborn knees. Steely heart, be soft as a newborn babe, so I can pray. Perhaps everything will turn out okay after all. (he kneels)
he kneels)

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET enters.

paragraphs.original:
Now might I do it pat. Now he is a-praying.
And now I'll do 't. And so he goes to heaven.
And so am I revenged. - That would be scanned.
A villain kills my father, and, for that,
I, his sole son, do this same villain send
To heaven.
Oh, this is hire and salary, not revenge.
He took my father grossly, full of bread,
With all his crimes broad blown, as flush as May.
And how his audit stands who knows save heaven?
But in our circumstance and course of thought
'Tis heavy with him. And am I then revenged
paragraphs.translated:
I could do it easily now. He's praying now. And now I'll do it. (he draws out his sword) And there he goes, off to heaven. And that's my revenge. I'd better think about this more carefully. A villain kills my father, and I, my father's only son, send this same villain to heaven. Seems like I just did him a favor. He killed my father when my father was enjoying life, with all his sins in full bloom, before my father could repent for any of them. Only God knows how many sins my father has to pay for. As for me, I don't think his prospects look so good.
(he draws out his sword)

paragraphs.original:
To take him in the purging of his soul
When he is fit and seasoned for his passage?
No.
Up, sword, and know thou a more horrid hent.
When he is drunk asleep, or in his rage,
Or in th' incestuous pleasure of his bed,
At game a-swearing, or about some act
That has no relish of salvation in 't - 
Then trip him, that his heels may kick at heaven,
And that his soul may be as damned and black
As hell, whereto it goes. My mother stays
This physic but prolongs thy sickly days.
paragraphs.translated:
So is it really revenge for me if I kill Claudius right when he is confessing his sins, in perfect condition for a trip to heaven? No. Away, sword, and wait for a better moment to kill him. (he puts his sword away) When he's sleeping off some drunken orgy, or having incestuous sex, or swearing while he gambles, or committing some other act that has no goodness about it - that's when I'll trip him up and send him to hell with his heels kicking up at heaven. My mother's waiting. The king's trying to cure himself with prayer, but all he's doing is keeping himself alive a little longer.
(he puts his sword away)

paragraphs.original: Exit HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET exits.

paragraphs.original:
(rises) My words fly up, my thoughts remain below.
(rises)
Words without thoughts never to heaven go.
paragraphs.translated:
(rising) My words fly up toward heaven, but my thoughts stay down here on earth. Words without thoughts behind them will never make it to heaven.
(rising)

paragraphs.original: Exit
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS exits.

paragraphs.original: Enter GERTRUDE and POLONIUS
paragraphs.translated: GERTRUDEand POLONIUS enter.

paragraphs.original:
He will come straight. Look you lay home to him.
Tell him his pranks have been too broad to bear with,
And that your grace hath screened and stood between
Much heat and him. I'll silence me even here.
Pray you, be round with him.
paragraphs.translated: He'll come right away. Make sure you lay into him. Tell him his pranks have caused too much trouble, and that Your Highness has taken a lot of heat for them. I'll be right here, silent. Please be blunt with him.

paragraphs.original:
(within) Mother, mother, mother!
(within)
paragraphs.translated:
(offstage) Mother, mother, mother!
(offstage)

paragraphs.original: I'll warrant you. Fear me not. Withdraw, I hear him coming.
paragraphs.translated: Don't worry, I'll do what you say. Now hide, I hear him coming.

paragraphs.original: POLONIUS hides behind the arras
paragraphs.translated: POLONIUS hides behind the tapestry.

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET enters.

paragraphs.original: Now mother, what's the matter?
paragraphs.translated: Now mother, what's this all about?

paragraphs.original: Hamlet, thou hast thy father much offended.
paragraphs.translated: Hamlet, you've insulted your father.

paragraphs.original: Mother, you have my father much offended.
paragraphs.translated: Mother, you've insulted my father.

paragraphs.original: Come, come, you answer with an idle tongue.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, you're answering me foolishly.

paragraphs.original: Go, go, you question with a wicked tongue.
paragraphs.translated: Go on, you're questioning me evilly.

paragraphs.original: Why, how now, Hamlet?
paragraphs.translated: Hamlet, what, why?

paragraphs.original: What's the matter now?
paragraphs.translated: What's the problem now?

paragraphs.original: Have you forgot me?
paragraphs.translated: Have you forgotten who I am?

paragraphs.original:
No, by the rood, not so.
You are the queen, your husband's brother's wife,
And - would it were not so! - you are my mother.
paragraphs.translated: For God's sake no, I haven't. You are the queen, your husband's brother's wife, and you are my mother, though I wish you weren't.

paragraphs.original: Nay, then I'll set those to you that can speak.
paragraphs.translated: In that case I'll call in others who can still speak.

paragraphs.original:
Come, come, and sit you down. You shall not budge.
You go not till I set you up a glass
Where you may see the inmost part of you.
paragraphs.translated: No, sit down. You won't budge until I hold a mirror up to you, where you will see what's deep inside you.

paragraphs.original:
What wilt thou do? Thou wilt not murder me?
Help, help, ho!
paragraphs.translated: What are you going to do? You won't kill me, will you? Help!

paragraphs.original:
(from behind the arras) What, ho? Help, help, help!
(from behind the arras)
paragraphs.translated:
(from behind the tapestry) Hey! Help, help, help!
(from behind the tapestry)

paragraphs.original: How now, a rat? Dead for a ducat, dead!
paragraphs.translated: What's this, a rat? I'll bet a buck he's a dead rat now.

paragraphs.original: (stabs his sword through the arras and kills POLONIUS)
paragraphs.translated: (he stabs his sword through the tapestry and kills POLONIUS)

paragraphs.original:
(from behind the arras) Oh, I am slain.
(from behind the arras)
paragraphs.translated:
(from behind the tapestry) Oh, I've been killed!
(from behind the tapestry)

paragraphs.original: O me, what hast thou done?
paragraphs.translated: Oh my God, what have you done?

paragraphs.original: Nay, I know not. Is it the king?
paragraphs.translated: I don't know. Is it the king?

paragraphs.original: Oh, what a rash and bloody deed is this!
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what a senseless, horrible act!

paragraphs.original:
A bloody deed? Almost as bad, good mother,
As kill a king and marry with his brother.
paragraphs.translated: A horrible act - almost as bad, my good mother, as killing a king and marrying his brother.

paragraphs.original: As kill a king?
paragraphs.translated: Killing a king?

paragraphs.original: Ay, lady, 'twas my word.
paragraphs.translated: That's what I said, my good woman.

paragraphs.original: (draws back the arras and discovers POLONIUS)
paragraphs.translated: (he pulls back the tapestry and discovers POLONIUS)

paragraphs.original:
Thou wretched, rash, intruding fool, farewell.
I took thee for thy better. Take thy fortune.
Thou find'st to be too busy is some danger.
