Hamlet's so careless, high-minded, and unsuspecting that he won't examine the swords beforehand, so you can easily choose one with a sharpened point and in one thrust avenge the death of your father.

paragraphs.original:
I will do 't.
And for that purpose I'll anoint my sword.
I bought an unction of a mountebank,
So mortal that, but dip a knife in it,
Where it draws blood no cataplasm so rare,
Collected from all simples that have virtue
Under the moon, can save the thing from death
That is but scratched withal. I'll touch my point
With this contagion, that if I gall him slightly
It may be death.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do it, and I'll put a little dab of something on my sword as well. From a quack doctor I bought some oil so poisonous that if you dip a knife in it, no medicine in the world can save the person who's scratched by it. If I even graze his skin slightly, he's likely to die.

paragraphs.original:
Let's further think of this,
Weigh what convenience both of time and means
May fit us to our shape. If this should fail,
And that our drift look through our bad performance,
'Twere better not assayed. Therefore this project
paragraphs.translated:
Let's think about this, and consider what time and what method will be most appropriate. If our plan were to fail, and people found out about it, it would be better never to have tried it.
We should have a backup ready in case the first plan doesn't work. Let me think. We'll place bets on you and Hamlet - that's it! When the two of you have gotten all sweaty and hot - keep him jumping around a lot for that purpose - Hamlet will ask for something to drink. I'll have a cup ready for him. If by chance he

paragraphs.original:
Should have a back or second that might hold
If this should blast in proof. - Soft, let me see. - 
We'll make a solemn wager on your cunnings. - 
I ha 't! When in your motion you are hot and dry,
As make your bouts more violent to that end,
And that he calls for drink, I'll have prepared him
A chalice for the nonce, whereon but sipping,
If he by chance escape your venomed stuck,
Our purpose may hold there. - But stay, what noise?
paragraphs.translated: escapes your poisoned sword tip, the drink will kill him. But wait, what's that sound?

paragraphs.original: Enter GERTRUDE
paragraphs.translated: GERTRUDE enters.

paragraphs.original:
One woe doth tread upon another's heel,
So fast they follow. - Your sister's drowned, Laertes.
paragraphs.translated: The bad news just keeps on coming, one disaster after another. Your sister's drowned, Laertes.

paragraphs.original: Drowned? Oh, where?
paragraphs.translated: Drowned? Oh, where?

paragraphs.original:
There is a willow grows aslant a brook
That shows his hoar leaves in the glassy stream.
There with fantastic garlands did she come
Of crowflowers, nettles, daisies, and long purples,
That liberal shepherds give a grosser name,
But our cold maids do "dead men's fingers" call them.
There, on the pendant boughs her coronet weeds
Clambering to hang, an envious sliver broke,
When down her weedy trophies and herself
Fell in the weeping brook. Her clothes spread wide,
And mermaid-like a while they bore her up,
Which time she chanted snatches of old lauds
As one incapable of her own distress,
Or like a creature native and indued
Unto that element. But long it could not be
Till that her garments, heavy with their drink,
Pulled the poor wretch from her melodious lay
To muddy death.
paragraphs.translated: There's a willow that leans over the brook, dangling its white leaves over the glassy water. Ophelia made wild wreaths out of those leaves, braiding in crowflowers, thistles, daisies, and the orchises that vulgar shepherds have an obscene name for, but which pure-minded girls call "dead men's fingers." Climbing into the tree to hang the wreath of weeds on the hanging branches, she and her flowers fell into the gurgling brook. Her clothes spread out wide in the water, and buoyed her up for a while as she sang bits of old hymns, acting like someone who doesn't realize the danger she's in, or like someone completely accustomed to danger. But it was only a matter of time before her clothes, heavy with the water they absorbed, pulled the poor thing out of her song, down into the mud at the bottom of the brook.

paragraphs.original: Alas, then she is drowned.
paragraphs.translated: So she is drowned.

paragraphs.original: Drowned, drowned.
paragraphs.translated: Drowned, drowned.

paragraphs.original:
Too much of water hast thou, poor Ophelia,
And therefore I forbid my tears. But yet
It is our trick. Nature her custom holds,
Let shame say what it will. When these are gone,
The woman will be out. - Adieu, my lord.
I have a speech of fire that fain would blaze,
But that this folly doubts it.
paragraphs.translated: You've had too much water already, poor Ophelia, so I won't shed watery tears for you. But crying is what humans do. We do what's in our nature, even if we're ashamed of it. After I stop crying I'll be through acting like a woman. Good-bye, my lord. I have some fiery words I could speak now, but my foolish tears are drowning them out.

paragraphs.original: Exit LAERTES
paragraphs.translated: LAERTES exits.

paragraphs.original:
Let's follow, Gertrude.
How much I had to do to calm his rage!
Now fear I this will give it start again.
Therefore let's follow.
paragraphs.translated: Let's follow him, Gertrude. I worked so hard to calm him down, and now I'm worried he's getting all excited again. Let's follow him.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter a GRAVEDIGGER and the OTHER gravedigger
paragraphs.translated: A GRAVEDIGGER and the OTHER gravedigger enter.

paragraphs.original: Is she to be buried in Christian burial when she willfully seeks her own salvation?
paragraphs.translated:
Are they really going to give her a Christian burial
after she killed herself?
after she killed herself?

paragraphs.original: I tell thee she is. Therefore make her grave straight. The crowner hath sat on her and finds it Christian burial.
paragraphs.translated: I'm telling you, yes. So finish that grave right away. The coroner examined her case and says it should be a Christian funeral.

paragraphs.original: How can that be, unless she drowned herself in her own defense?
paragraphs.translated: But how, unless she drowned in self-defense?

paragraphs.original: Why, 'tis found so.
paragraphs.translated: That's what they're saying she did.

paragraphs.original:
It must be se offendendo. It cannot be else. For here lies the point: if I drown myself wittingly, it argues an act. And an act hath three branches - it is to act, to do, to perform. Argal, she drowned herself wittingly.
se offendendo
paragraphs.translated: Sounds more like "self-offense," if you ask me. What I'm saying is, if she knew she was drowning herself, then that's an act. An act has three sides to it: to do, to act, and to perform. Therefore she must have known she was drowning herself.

paragraphs.original: Nay, but hear you, Goodman Delver -
paragraphs.translated: No, listen here, gravedigger sir -

paragraphs.original: Give me leave. Here lies the water. Good. Here stands the man. Good. If the man go to this water and drown himself, it is, will he nill he, he goes. Mark you that. But if the water come to him and drown him, he drowns not himself. Argal, he that is not guilty of his own death shortens not his own life.
paragraphs.translated: Let me finish. Here's the water, right? And here's a man, okay? If the man goes into the water and drowns himself, he's the one doing it, like it or not. But if the water comes to him and drowns him, then he doesn't drown himself. Therefore, he who is innocent of his own death does not shorten his own life.

paragraphs.original: But is this law?
paragraphs.translated: Is that how the law sees it?

paragraphs.original: Ay, marry, is 't. Crowner's quest law.
paragraphs.translated: It sure is. The coroner's inquest law.

paragraphs.original: Will you ha' the truth on 't? If this had not been a gentlewoman, she should have been buried out o' Christian burial.
paragraphs.translated: Do you want to know the truth? If this woman hadn't been rich, she wouldn't have been given a Christian burial.

paragraphs.original: Why, there thou sayst. And the more pity that great folk should have countenance in this world to drown or hang themselves more than their even Christian. Come, my spade. There is no ancient gentleman but gardeners, ditchers, and grave-makers. They hold up Adam's profession.
paragraphs.translated: Well there, now you've said it. It's a pity that the rich have more freedom to hang or drown themselves than the rest of us Christians. Come on, shovel. The most ancient aristocrats in the world are gardeners, ditch-diggers, and gravediggers. They keep up Adam's profession.

paragraphs.original: Was he a gentleman?
paragraphs.translated: Was he an aristocrat? With a coat of arms?

paragraphs.original: He was the first that ever bore arms.
paragraphs.translated: He was the first person who ever had arms.

paragraphs.original: Why, he had none.
paragraphs.translated: He didn't have any.

paragraphs.original: What, art a heathen? How dost thou understand the Scripture? The Scripture says Adam digged. Could he dig without arms? I'll put another question to thee. If thou answerest me not to the purpose, confess thyself -
paragraphs.translated: What, aren't you a Christian? The Bible says Adam dug in the ground. How could he dig without arms? I'll ask you another question. If you can't answer it -

paragraphs.original: Go to.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead!

paragraphs.original: What is he that builds stronger than either the mason, the shipwright, or the carpenter?
paragraphs.translated: What do you call a person who builds stronger things than a stonemason, a shipbuilder, or a carpenter does?

paragraphs.original: The gallows-maker, for that frame outlives a thousand tenants.
paragraphs.translated: The one who builds the gallows to hang people on, since his structure outlives a thousand inhabitants.

paragraphs.original: I like thy wit well, in good faith. The gallows does well, but how does it well? It does well to those that do ill.
paragraphs.translated: You're funny, and I like that. The gallows do a good job. But how? It does a good job for those who do bad.

paragraphs.original: Now thou dost ill to say the gallows is built stronger than the church. Argal, the gallows may do well to thee. To 't again, come.
paragraphs.translated:
Now, it's wrong to say that the gallows are stronger than a church. Therefore, the gallows may do you some good. Come on, your turn.
you

paragraphs.original: "Who builds stronger than a mason, a shipwright, or a carpenter?"
paragraphs.translated: Let's see, "Who builds stronger things than a stonemason, a shipbuilder, or a carpenter?"

paragraphs.original: Ay, tell me that, and unyoke.
paragraphs.translated: That's the question, so answer it.

paragraphs.original: Marry, now I can tell.
paragraphs.translated: Ah, I've got it!

paragraphs.original: To 't.
paragraphs.translated: Go ahead.

paragraphs.original: Mass, I cannot tell.
paragraphs.translated: Damn, I forgot.

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET and HORATIO afar off
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and HORATIO enter in the distance.

paragraphs.original: Cudgel thy brains no more about it, for your dull ass will not mend his pace with beating. And when you are asked this question next, say "A grave-maker." The houses that he makes last till doomsday. Go, get thee in. Fetch me a stoup of liquor.
paragraphs.translated: Don't beat your brains out over it. You can't make a slow donkey run by beating it. The next time someone asks you this riddle, say "a gravedigger." The houses he makes last till Judgment Day. Now go and get me some booze.

paragraphs.original: Exit OTHER
paragraphs.translated: The OTHER GRAVEDIGGER exits.

paragraphs.original:
(digs and sings)
(digs and sings)
In youth when I did love, did love,
In youth when I did love, did love
Methought it was very sweet
Methought it was very sweet
To contract–o–the time, for–a–my behove,
To contract–o–the time, for–a–my behove
Oh, methought, there–a–was nothing–a–meet.
Oh, methought, there–a–was nothing–a–meet
paragraphs.translated:
(the GRAVEDIGGER digs and sings)
(the
digs and sings)
In my youth I loved, I loved,
In my youth I loved, I loved
And I thought it was very sweet
And I thought it was very sweet
To set - ohh - the date for - ahh - my duty
To set - ohh - the date for - ahh - my duty
Oh, I thought it - ahh - was not right.
Oh, I thought it - ahh - was not right

paragraphs.original: Has this fellow no feeling of his business? He sings at grave- making.
paragraphs.translated: Doesn't this guy realize what he's doing? He's singing while digging a grave.

paragraphs.original: Custom hath made it in him a property of easiness.
paragraphs.translated: He's gotten so used to graves that they don't bother him anymore.

paragraphs.original: 'Tis e'en so. The hand of little employment hath the daintier sense.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, exactly. Only people who don't have to work can afford to be sensitive.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
But age with his stealing steps
But age with his stealing steps
Hath clawed me in his clutch,
Hath clawed me in his clutch
And hath shipped me into the land
And hath shipped me into the land
As if I had never been such.
As if I had never been such
(throws up a skull)
(throws up a skull)
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
But old age has sneaked up on me
But old age has sneaked up on me
And grabbed me in his claws,
And grabbed me in his claws
And has shipped me into the ground
And has shipped me into the ground
As if I'd never been like that.
As if I'd never been like that
(he throws up a skull)
(he throws up a skull)

paragraphs.original: That skull had a tongue in it and could sing once. How the knave jowls it to the ground, as if it were Cain's jawbone, that did the first murder! It might be the pate of a politician, which this ass now o'erreaches, one that would circumvent God, might it not?
paragraphs.translated: That skull had a tongue in it once and could sing. That jackass is throwing it around as if it belonged to Cain, who did the first murder! It might be the skull of a politician once capable of talking his way around God, right? And now this idiot is pulling rank on him.

paragraphs.original: It might, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Indeed, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Or of a courtier, which could say, "Good morrow, sweet lord!" "How dost thou, good lord?" This might be my Lord Such-a-one that praised my Lord Such-a-one's horse when he meant to beg it, might it not?
paragraphs.translated: Or a courtier, who could say things like, "Good night, my sweet lord! How are you doing, good lord?" This might be the skull of Lord So-and-So, who praised Lord Such-and-Such's horse when he wanted to borrow it, right?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Why, e'en so. And now my Lady Worm's, chapless and knocked about the mazard with a sexton's spade. Here's fine revolution, an we had the trick to see 't. Did these bones cost no more the breeding but to play at loggets with them? Mine ache to think on 't.
paragraphs.translated: Exactly. And now it's the property of Lady Worm, its lower jaw knocked off and thwacked on the noggin with a shovel. That's quite a reversal of fortune, isn't it, if we could only see it? Are these bones worth nothing more than bowling pins now? It makes my bones ache to think about it.

paragraphs.original:
(sings)
(sings)
A pickax and a spade, a spade,
A pickax and a spade, a spade
For and a shrouding sheet,
For and a shrouding sheet
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.
For such a guest is meet
(throws up another skull)
(throws up another skull)
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
A pickax and a shovel, a shovel,
A pickax and a shovel, a shovel
And a sheet for a funeral shroud,
And a sheet for a funeral shroud
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
For a guest like this one here.
For a guest like this one here
(he throws up another skull)
(he throws up another skull)

paragraphs.original: There's another. Why may not that be the skull of a lawyer? Where be his quiddities now, his quillities, his cases, his tenures, and his tricks? Why does he suffer this rude knave now to knock him about the sconce with a dirty shovel and will not tell him of his action of battery? Hum! This fellow might be in 's time a great buyer of land, with his statutes, his recognizances, his fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries. Is this the fine of his fines and the recovery of his recoveries, to have his fine pate full of fine dirt? Will his vouchers vouch him no more of his purchases, and double ones too, than the length and breadth of a pair of indentures? The very conveyances of his lands will hardly lie in this box, and must the inheritor himself have no more, ha?
paragraphs.translated: There's another. Could that be a lawyer's skull? Where's all his razzle-dazzle legal jargon now? Why does he allow this idiot to knock him on the head with a dirty shovel, instead of suing him for assault and battery? Maybe this guy was once a great landowner, with his deeds and contracts, his tax shelters and his annuities. Is it part of his deed of ownership to have his skull filled up with dirt? Does he only get to keep as much land as a set of contracts would cover if you spread them out on the ground? The deeds to his properties would barely fit in this coffin - and the coffin's all the property he gets to keep?

paragraphs.original: Not a jot more, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: No more than that, my lord.

paragraphs.original: Is not parchment made of sheepskins?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't the parchment of a legal document made of sheepskin?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my lord, and of calfskins too.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord, and calfskin too.

paragraphs.original:
They are sheep and calves which seek out assurance in that.
I will speak to this fellow. - Whose grave's this, sirrah?
paragraphs.translated: Anyone who puts his trust in such documents is a sheep or a calf. I'll talk to this guy. - Excuse me, sir, whose grave is this?

paragraphs.original:
Mine, sir.
(sings)
(sings)
paragraphs.translated: It's mine, sir.

paragraphs.original:
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
Oh, a pit of clay for to be made
For such a guest is meet.
For such a guest is meet
paragraphs.translated:
(sings)
(sings)
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
Oh, a pit of dirt is what we need
For a guest like this one here.
For a guest like this one here

paragraphs.original: I think it be thine, indeed, for thou liest in 't.
paragraphs.translated: I think it really must be yours, since you're the one lying in it.

paragraphs.original: You lie out on 't, sir, and therefore it is not yours. For my part, I do not lie in 't, and yet it is mine.
paragraphs.translated: And you're lying outside of it, so it's not yours. As for me, I'm not lying to you in it - it's really mine.

paragraphs.original: Thou dost lie in 't, to be in 't and say it is thine. 'Tis for the dead, not for the quick. Therefore thou liest.
paragraphs.translated:
But you are lying in it, being in it and saying it's yours. It's for the dead, not the living. So you're lying.
are

paragraphs.original: 'Tis a quick lie, sir. 'Twill away gain from me to you.
paragraphs.translated: That's a lively lie, sir - it jumps so fast from me to you.

paragraphs.original: What man dost thou dig it for?
paragraphs.translated: What man are you digging it for?

paragraphs.original: For no man, sir.
paragraphs.translated: For no man, sir.

paragraphs.original: What woman, then?
paragraphs.translated: What woman, then?

paragraphs.original: For none, neither.
paragraphs.translated: For no woman, either.

paragraphs.original: Who is to be buried in 't?
paragraphs.translated: Who's to be buried in it?

paragraphs.original: One that was a woman, sir, but, rest her soul, she's dead.
paragraphs.translated: One who used to be a woman but - bless her soul - is dead now.

paragraphs.original: How absolute the knave is! We must speak by the card, or equivocation will undo us. By the Lord, Horatio, these three years I have taken a note of it. The age is grown so picked that the toe of the peasant comes so near the heel of the courtier he galls his kibe. - How long hast thou been a grave-maker?
paragraphs.translated: How literal this guy is! We have to speak precisely, or he'll get the better of us with his wordplay. Lord, Horatio, I've been noticing this for a few years now. The peasants have become so clever and witty that they're nipping at the heels of noblemen. - How long have you been a gravedigger?

paragraphs.original:
Of all the days i' the year, I came to 't that day that our last
King Hamlet overcame Fortinbras.
paragraphs.translated: Of all the days in the year, I started the day that the late King Hamlet defeated Fortinbras.

paragraphs.original: How long is that since?
paragraphs.translated: How long ago was that?

paragraphs.original: Cannot you tell that? Every fool can tell that. It was the very day that young Hamlet was born, he that is mad and sent into England.
paragraphs.translated: You don't know that? Any fool could tell you, it was the day that young Hamlet was born - the one who went crazy and got sent off to England.

paragraphs.original: Ay, marry, why was he sent into England?
paragraphs.translated: Why was he sent to England?

paragraphs.original: Why, because he was mad. He shall recover his wits there, or, if he do not, it's no great matter there.
paragraphs.translated: Because he was crazy. He'll recover his sanity there. Or if he doesn't, it won't matter in England.

paragraphs.original: Why?
paragraphs.translated: Why not?

paragraphs.original: 'Twill not be seen in him there. There the men are as mad as he.
paragraphs.translated: Because nobody will notice he's crazy. Everyone there is as crazy as he is.

paragraphs.original: How came he mad?
paragraphs.translated: How did he go crazy?

paragraphs.original: Very strangely, they say.
paragraphs.translated: In a strange way, they say.

paragraphs.original: How "strangely"?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean, "in a strange way"?

paragraphs.original: Faith, e'en with losing his wits.
paragraphs.translated: By losing his mind.

paragraphs.original: Upon what ground?
paragraphs.translated: On what grounds?

paragraphs.original: Why, here in Denmark. I have been sexton here, man and boy, thirty years.
paragraphs.translated: Right here in Denmark. I've been the church warden here for thirty years, since childhood.

paragraphs.original: How long will a man lie i' the earth ere he rot?
paragraphs.translated: How long will a man lie in his grave before he starts to rot?

paragraphs.original: Faith, if he be not rotten before he die - as we have many pocky corses nowadays that will scarce hold the laying in -  he will last you some eight year or nine year. A tanner will last you nine year.
paragraphs.translated: Well, if he's not rotten before he dies (and there are a lot of people now who are so rotten they start falling to pieces even before you put them in the coffin), he'll last eight or nine years. A leathermaker will last nine years.

paragraphs.original: Why he more than another?
paragraphs.translated: Why does he last longer?

paragraphs.original:
Why, sir, his hide is so tanned with his trade that he will keep out water a great while, and your water is a sore decayer of your whoreson dead body. (indicates a skull) Here's a skull now. This skull has lain in the earth three-and-twenty years.
(indicates a skull)
paragraphs.translated: Because his hide is so leathery from his trade that he keeps the water off him a long time, and water is what makes your goddamn body rot more than anything. Here's a skull that's been here twenty-three years.

paragraphs.original: Whose was it?
paragraphs.translated: Whose was it?

paragraphs.original: A whoreson mad fellow's it was. Whose do you think it was?
paragraphs.translated: A crazy bastard. Who do you think?

paragraphs.original: Nay, I know not.
paragraphs.translated: I really don't know.

paragraphs.original: A pestilence on him for a mad rogue! He poured a flagon of Rhenish on my head once. This same skull, sir, was Yorick's skull, the king's jester.
paragraphs.translated: Damn that crazy madman! He poured a pitcher of white wine on my head once. This is the skull of Yorick, the king's jester.

paragraphs.original: This?
paragraphs.translated: This one?

paragraphs.original: E'en that.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, that one.

paragraphs.original:
Let me see. (takes the skull) Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio, a fellow of infinite jest, of most excellent fancy. He hath borne me on his back a thousand times, and now, how abhorred in my imagination it is! My gorge rises at it. Here hung those lips that I have kissed I know not how oft.  - Where be your gibes now? Your gambols? Your songs? Your flashes of merriment that were wont to set the table on a roar? Not one now to mock your own grinning? Quite chapfallen? Now get you to my lady's chamber and tell her, let her paint an inch thick, to this favor she must come. Make her laugh at that. - Prithee, Horatio, tell me one thing.
(takes the skull)
paragraphs.translated:
Let me see. (he takes the skull) Oh, poor Yorick! I used to know him, Horatio - a very funny guy, and with an excellent imagination. He carried me on his back a thousand times, and now - how terrible - this is him. It makes my stomach turn. I don't know how many times I kissed the lips that used to be right here. Where are your jokes now? Your pranks? Your songs?
(he takes the skull)
Your flashes of wit that used to set the whole table laughing? You don't make anybody smile now. Are you sad about that? You need to go to my lady's room and tell her that no matter how much makeup she slathers on, she'll end up just like you some day. That'll make her laugh. Horatio, tell me something.

paragraphs.original: What's that, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: What's that, my lord?

paragraphs.original: Dost thou think Alexander looked o' this fashion i' th' earth?
paragraphs.translated: Do you think Alexander the Great looked like this when he was buried?

paragraphs.original: E'en so.
paragraphs.translated: Exactly like that.

paragraphs.original:
And smelt so? Pah! (puts down the skull)
(puts down the skull)
paragraphs.translated:
And smelled like that, too? Whew! (he puts down the skull)
(he puts down the skull)

paragraphs.original: E'en so, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Just as bad, my lord.

paragraphs.original: To what base uses we may return, Horatio. Why may not imagination trace the noble dust of Alexander till he find it stopping a bunghole?
paragraphs.translated: How low we can fall, Horatio. Isn't it possible to imagine that the noble ashes of Alexander the Great could end up plugging a hole in a barrel?

paragraphs.original: 'Twere to consider too curiously, to consider so.
paragraphs.translated: If you thought that you'd be thinking too much.

paragraphs.original:
No, faith, not a jot. But to follow him thither with modesty enough, and likelihood to lead it, as thus: Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander returneth to dust, the dust is earth, of earth we make loam - and why of that loam, whereto he was converted, might they not stop a beer barrel?
Imperious Caesar, dead and turned to clay,
Might stop a hole to keep the wind away.
Oh, that that earth, which kept the world in awe,
Should patch a wall t' expel the winter's flaw!
But soft, but soft a while.
paragraphs.translated: No, not at all. Just follow the logic: Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander returned to dust, the dust is dirt, and dirt makes mud we use to stop up holes. So why can't someone plug a beer barrel with the dirt that used to be Alexander? The great emperor Caesar, dead and turned to clay, might plug up a hole to keep the wind away. Oh, to think that the same body that once ruled the world could now patch up a wall! But quiet, be quiet a minute.

paragraphs.original: Enter King CLAUDIUS, Queen GERTRUDE, LAERTES, and a coffin, with a PRIEST and other lords attendant.
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS enters with GERTRUDE, LAERTES, and a coffin, with a PRIEST and other lords attendant.

paragraphs.original:
Here comes the king,
The queen, the courtiers - who is this they follow,
And with such maimèd rites? This doth betoken
The corse they follow did with desperate hand
Fordo its own life. 'Twas of some estate.
Couch we a while and mark.
paragraphs.translated: Here comes the king, the queen, and the noblemen of court. Who are they following? And with such a plain and scrawny ceremony? It means the corpse they're following took its own life. Must have been from a wealthy family. Let's stay and watch a while.

paragraphs.original: HAMLET and HORATIO withdraw
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and HORATIO step aside.

paragraphs.original: What ceremony else?
paragraphs.translated: What other rites are you going to give her?

paragraphs.original: That is Laertes, a very noble youth, mark.
paragraphs.translated: That's Laertes, a very noble young man. Listen.

paragraphs.original: What ceremony else?
paragraphs.translated: What other rites are you going to give her?

paragraphs.original:
Her obsequies have been as far enlarged
As we have warranty. Her death was doubtful,
And, but that great command o'ersways the order,
She should in ground unsanctified have lodged
Till the last trumpet. For charitable prayers
Shards, flints and pebbles should be thrown on her.
Yet here she is allowed her virgin crants,
Her maiden strewments, and the bringing home
Of bell and burial.
paragraphs.translated: I've performed as many rites as I'm permitted. Her death was suspicious, and were it not for the fact that the king gave orders to bury her here, she'd have been buried outside the church graveyard. She deserves to have rocks and stones thrown on her body. But she has had prayers read for her and is dressed up like a pure virgin, with flowers tossed on her grave and the bell tolling for her.

paragraphs.original: Must there no more be done?
paragraphs.translated: Isn't there any other rite you can perform?

paragraphs.original:
No more be done.
We should profane the service of the dead
To sing a requiem and such rest to her
As to peace-parted souls.
paragraphs.translated: No, nothing. We would profane the other dead souls here if we sang the same requiem for her that we sang for them.

paragraphs.original:
Lay her i' th' earth,
And from her fair and unpolluted flesh
May violets spring! I tell thee, churlish priest,
A ministering angel shall my sister be
When thou liest howling.
paragraphs.translated:
Lay her in the ground, and let violets bloom from her lovely and pure flesh!
I'm telling you, you jerk priest, my sister will be an angel in heaven while you're howling in hell.

paragraphs.original:
Sweets to the sweet. Farewell! (scatters flowers)
(scatters flowers)
I hoped thou shouldst have been my Hamlet's wife.
I thought thy bride-bed to have decked, sweet maid,
And not have strewed thy grave.
paragraphs.translated:
Sweet flowers for a sweet girl. Goodbye! (she scatters flowers) I once hoped you'd be my Hamlet's wife. I thought I'd be tossing flowers on your wedding bed, my sweet girl, not on your grave.
(she scatters flowers)

paragraphs.original:
Oh, treble woe
Fall ten times treble on that cursèd head,
Whose wicked deed thy most ingenious sense
Deprived thee of! Hold off the earth awhile
Till I have caught her once more in mine arms.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, damn three times, damn ten times the evil man whose wicked deed deprived you of your ingenious mind. Hold off burying her until I've caught her in my arms once more.

paragraphs.original: (leaps into the grave)
paragraphs.translated: (he jumps into the grave)

paragraphs.original:
Now pile your dust upon the quick and dead,
Till of this flat a mountain you have made,
T' o'ertop old Pelion or the skyish head
Of blue Olympus.
paragraphs.translated:
Now pile the dirt onto the living and the dead alike, till you've made a mountain higher than
Mount Pelion or Mount Olympus.
Mount Pelion or Mount Olympus

paragraphs.original:
(comes forward) What is he whose grief
(comes forward)
Bears such an emphasis, whose phrase of sorrow
Conjures the wandering stars, and makes them stand
Like wonder-wounded hearers? This is I,
Hamlet the Dane. (leaps into the grave)
(leaps into the grave)
paragraphs.translated:
(coming forward) Who is the one whose grief is so loud and clear, whose words of sadness make the planets stand still in the heavens as if they've been hurt by what they've heard? It's me, Hamlet the Dane. (he jumps into the grave)
(coming forward)
(he jumps into the grave)

paragraphs.original: The devil take thy soul!
paragraphs.translated: To hell with your soul!

paragraphs.original: HAMLET and LAERTES grapple
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and LAERTES wrestle with each other.

paragraphs.original:
Thou pray'st not well.
I prithee, take thy fingers from my throat,
For though I am not splenitive and rash,
Yet have I something in me dangerous,
Which let thy wisdom fear. Hold off thy hand.
paragraphs.translated:
That's no way to pray. (they fight) Please take your hands off my throat. I may not be rash and quick to anger, but I have something dangerous in me which you should beware of. Take your hands off.
(they fight)

paragraphs.original: Pluck them asunder.
paragraphs.translated: Pull them apart.

paragraphs.original: Hamlet, Hamlet!
paragraphs.translated: Hamlet! Hamlet!

paragraphs.original: Gentlemen -
paragraphs.translated: Gentlemen!

paragraphs.original: Attendants separate HAMLET and LAERTES
paragraphs.translated: Attendants separate HAMLET and LAERTES

paragraphs.original:
Why, I will fight with him upon this theme
Until my eyelids will no longer wag.
paragraphs.translated: I'll fight him over this issue till I don't have the strength to blink.

paragraphs.original: O my son, what theme?
paragraphs.translated: Oh, my son, what issue is that?

paragraphs.original:
I loved Ophelia. Forty thousand brothers
Could not with all their quantity of love
Make up my sum. What wilt thou do for her?
paragraphs.translated: I loved Ophelia. Forty thousand brothers, if you added all their love together, couldn't match mine. What are you going to do for her?

paragraphs.original: O, he is mad, Laertes.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, he's crazy, Laertes!

paragraphs.original: For love of God, forbear him.
paragraphs.translated: For the love of God, be patient with him.

paragraphs.original:
'Swounds, show me what thou'lt do.
Woo't weep? Woo't fight? Woo't fast? Woo't tear thyself?
Woo't drink up eisel, eat a crocodile?
I'll do 't. Dost thou come here to whine,
To outface me with leaping in her grave?
Be buried quick with her? - and so will I.
And if thou prate of mountains let them throw
Millions of acres on us, till our ground,
Singeing his pate against the burning zone,
Make Ossa like a wart! Nay, an thou'lt mouth,
I'll rant as well as thou.
paragraphs.translated: Damn it, show me what you're going to do for her. Will you cry? Fight? Stop eating? Cut yourself? Drink vinegar? Eat a crocodile? I'll do all that. Did you come here to whine? To outdo me by jumping into her grave so theatrically? To be buried alive with her? So will I. And if you rattle on about mountains, then let them throw millions of acres over us. It will be so high a peak that it scrapes against heaven and makes Mount Ossa look like a wart. See? I can talk crazy as well as you.

paragraphs.original:
This is mere madness.
And thus a while the fit will work on him.
Anon, as patient as the female dove
When that her golden couplets are disclosed,
His silence will sit drooping.
paragraphs.translated: This is pure insanity. He'll be like this for a little while. Then he'll be as calm and quiet as a dove waiting for her eggs to hatch.

paragraphs.original:
Hear you, sir.
What is the reason that you use me thus?
I loved you ever. But it is no matter.
Let Hercules himself do what he may,
The cat will mew and dog will have his day.
paragraphs.translated: Listen, sir, why do you treat me like this? I always loved you. But it doesn't matter. Even a hero like Hercules can't keep cats from acting like cats, and dogs like dogs.

paragraphs.original: Exit HAMLET
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET exits.

paragraphs.original: I pray thee, good Horatio, wait upon him.
paragraphs.translated: Please, Horatio, go with him.

paragraphs.original: Exit HORATIO
paragraphs.translated: HORATIO exits.

paragraphs.original:
(to LAERTES) Strengthen your patience in our last night's speech.
(to
)
We'll put the matter to the present push. - 
Good Gertrude, set some watch over your son. - 
This grave shall have a living monument.
An hour of quiet shortly shall we see.
Till then in patience our proceeding be.
Exeunt
paragraphs.translated: They exit.

paragraphs.original: Enter HAMLET and HORATIO
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and HORATIO enter.

paragraphs.original:
So much for this, sir. Now shall you see the other.
You do remember all the circumstance?
paragraphs.translated: That's enough about that. Now I'll tell you the other story about my journey. Do you remember the circumstances?

paragraphs.original: Remember it, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: How could I forget, my lord!

paragraphs.original:
Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting
That would not let me sleep. Methought I lay
Worse than the mutines in the bilboes. Rashly - 
And praised be rashness for it: let us know
Our indiscretion sometimes serves us well
When our deep plots do pall, and that should teach us
There's a divinity that shapes our ends,
Rough-hew them how we will -
paragraphs.translated: There was a kind of war in my brain that wouldn't let me sleep. It was worse than being a captive in chains. Sometimes it's good to be rash - sometimes it works out well to act impulsively when our careful plans lose steam. This should show us that there's a God in heaven who's always guiding us in the right direction, however often we screw up -

paragraphs.original: That is most certain.
paragraphs.translated: Well, of course.

paragraphs.original:
Up from my cabin,
My sea-gown scarfed about me, in the dark
Groped I to find out them, had my desire,
Fingered their packet, and in fine withdrew
To mine own room again, making so bold
(My fears forgetting manners) to unseal
Their grand commission, where I found, Horatio - 
O royal knavery! - an exact command,
Larded with many several sorts of reasons
Importing Denmark's health, and England's too,
With - ho! - such bugs and goblins in my life
That, on the supervise (no leisure bated,
No, not to stay the grinding of the ax)
My head should be struck off.
paragraphs.translated: So I came up from my cabin with my robe tied around me, groped in the dark to find what I was looking for, found it, looked through their packet of papers, and returned to my cabin again. I was bold enough (I guess my fears made me forget my manners) to open the document containing the king's instructions. And there I found, Horatio, such royal mischief - a precisely worded order, sugared with lots of talk about Denmark's well-being and England's too, to cut off my head, without even waiting to sharpen the ax.

paragraphs.original: Is 't possible?
paragraphs.translated: Is it possible?

paragraphs.original:
(shows HORATIO a document)
(shows
a document)
Here's the commission. Read it at more leisure.
But wilt thou hear me how I did proceed?
paragraphs.translated:
(he shows HORATIO a document) Here's the document. Read it in your free time. But do you want to hear what I did then?
(he shows
a document)

paragraphs.original: I beseech you.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, please tell me.

paragraphs.original:
Being thus benetted round with villainies - 
Ere I could make a prologue to my brains,
They had begun the play - I sat me down,
Devised a new commission, wrote it fair.
I once did hold it, as our statists do,
A baseness to write fair, and labored much
How to forget that learning, but, sir, now
It did me yeoman's service. Wilt thou know
Th' effect of what I wrote?
paragraphs.translated: So there I was, caught in their evil net. Before I could even start processing the situation, they had started the ball rolling. I sat down and wrote out a new official document with new instructions. I wrote it in a bureaucrat's neat handwriting. I used to think having nice handwriting was for servants, just like our politicians think, and I had to work hard to overcome that prejudice - but it sure came in handy then. Do you want to know what I wrote?

paragraphs.original: Ay, good my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original:
An earnest conjuration from the king,
As England was his faithful tributary,
As love between them like the palm might flourish,
As peace should stiff her wheaten garland wear
And stand a comma 'tween their amities,
And many suchlike "as's" of great charge,
That, on the view and knowing of these contents,
Without debatement further, more or less,
He should the bearers put to sudden death,
Not shriving time allowed.
paragraphs.translated: A sincere plea from the king, who commands the respect of England, and who hopes that the love between the two countries can flourish, and that peace can join them in friendship - and other fancy mumbo jumbo like that - saying that, once they read this document, without any debate, the ones delivering the letter should be put to death immediately, without giving them time to confess to a priest.

paragraphs.original: How was this sealed?
paragraphs.translated: But how could you put an official seal on it?

paragraphs.original:
Why, even in that was heaven ordinant.
I had my father's signet in my purse,
Which was the model of that Danish seal.
Folded the writ up in form of th' other,
Subscribed it, gave 't th' impression, placed it safely,
The changeling never known. Now, the next day
Was our sea fight, and what to this was sequent
Thou know'st already.
paragraphs.translated: Heaven helped me out with that too. I had my father's signet ring in my pocket, with the royal seal of Denmark on it. I folded up the new document, signed it, sealed it, and put it safely back so that no one noticed any difference. The next day we had our fight at sea, and you know what happened after that.

paragraphs.original: So Guildenstern and Rosencrantz go to 't.
paragraphs.translated: So Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are in for it.

paragraphs.original:
Why, man, they did make love to this employment.
They are not near my conscience. Their defeat
Does by their own insinuation grow.
'Tis dangerous when the baser nature comes
Between the pass and fell incensèd points
Of mighty opposites.
paragraphs.translated: Man, they were asking for it. I don't feel guilty about them at all. They got what they deserved. It's always dangerous when little people get caught in the crossfire of mighty opponents.

paragraphs.original: Why, what a king is this!
paragraphs.translated: What a king Claudius is!

paragraphs.original:
Does it not, think thee, stand me now upon - 
He that hath killed my king and whored my mother,
Popped in between th' election and my hopes,
Thrown out his angle for my proper life
(And with such cozenage!) - is 't not perfect conscience
To quit him with this arm? And is 't not to be damned
To let this canker of our nature come
In further evil?
paragraphs.translated: Don't you think it's my duty now to kill him with this weapon? This man who killed my king, made my mother a whore, took the throne that I hoped for, and set a trap to kill me. Isn't it completely moral to kill him now with this sword - and an easy conscience? And wouldn't I be damned if I let this monster live to do more harm?

paragraphs.original:
It must be shortly known to him from England
What is the issue of the business there.
paragraphs.translated: He'll find out soon what happened in England.

paragraphs.original:
It will be short. The interim's mine.
And a man's life's no more than to say "one."
But I am very sorry, good Horatio,
That to Laertes I forgot myself,
For by the image of my cause I see
The portraiture of his. I'll court his favors.
But sure the bravery of his grief did put me
Into a towering passion.
paragraphs.translated: Soon enough. But I have the meantime. A human life is hardly long enough to count to one in. But I really feel bad, Horatio, about losing control of myself with Laertes. His situation is very much like my own. I'll be nice to him. It was just that the showiness of his grief sent me into a fury.

paragraphs.original: Peace. - Who comes here?
paragraphs.translated: Hang on a minute - who are you?

paragraphs.original: Enter young OSRIC, a courtier, hat in hand
paragraphs.translated: OSRIC, a young courtier, enters with his hat in his hand.

paragraphs.original: Your lordship is right welcome back to Denmark.
paragraphs.translated: Welcome back to Denmark, my lord.

Thank you kindly, sir. (speaking so that only HORATIO can hear) Do you know this insect?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

(speaking so that only HAMLET can hear) No, my lord.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

(speaking so that only HORATIO can hear) You're lucky, since knowing him is most unpleasant. He owns a lot of good land. Give an animal a lot of money, and he'll be welcome at the king's table. He's a jerk, but he owns a whole lot of dirt, so he's treated well.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Sweet lord, if your lordship were at leisure, I should impart a thing to you from His Majesty.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, if you have a free moment, I have a message from His Majesty.

paragraphs.original: I will receive it, sir, with all diligence of spirit. Put your bonnet to his right use. 'Tis for the head.
paragraphs.translated: I'll hang on every word you say. Put your hat back on, where it belongs: it's for your head, not for your hands to hold.

paragraphs.original: I thank your lordship. It is very hot.
paragraphs.translated: No thank you, my lord. It's very hot.

paragraphs.original: No, believe me, 'tis very cold. The wind is northerly.
paragraphs.translated: No, I'm telling you, it's very cold, with a northerly wind.

paragraphs.original: It is indifferent cold, my lord, indeed.
paragraphs.translated: It is rather cold, indeed, my lord.

paragraphs.original: But yet methinks it is very sultry and hot for my complexion.
paragraphs.translated: And yet I feel it's very hot and humid, which is bad for my complexion.

paragraphs.original: Exceedingly, my lord. It is very sultry - as 'twere - I cannot tell how. My lord, his majesty bade me signify to you that he has laid a great wager on your head. Sir, this is the matter -
paragraphs.translated: Yes indeed it is, sir. Very humid, I can't tell you how humid it is. My lord, His Majesty wanted me to tell you that he's placed a large bet on you. This is what it's all about -

paragraphs.original:
I beseech you, remember - (indicates that OSRIC should put on his hat)
(indicates that
should put on his hat)
paragraphs.translated:
Please, I beg you - (he points to OSRIC 's hat)
(he points to
's hat)

paragraphs.original: Nay, good my lord, for mine ease, in good faith. Sir, here is newly come to court Laertes, believe me, an absolute gentleman, full of most excellent differences, of very soft society and great showing. Indeed, to speak feelingly of him, he is the card or calendar of gentry, for you shall find in him the continent of what part a gentleman would see.
paragraphs.translated:
No, my lord, I'm comfortable like this, thank you. Sir, there's someone named Laertes who's recently come to the court. He's an absolute gentleman, totally outstanding in so many respects, very easy in society, and displaying all his excellent qualities.
If I were to expose my true feelings about him, I'd have to say he's like a business card for the upper classes - he's that wonderful. You'll find that he's the sum total of what a perfect gentleman should be.
If I were to expose my true feelings about him

paragraphs.original: Sir, his definement suffers no perdition in you, though I know to divide him inventorially would dizzy th' arithmetic of memory, and yet but yaw neither, in respect of his quick sail.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, your description of him doesn't detract from his good qualities, though I know that trying to list them all would make your head spin, and even so you wouldn't be able to keep up with him.

paragraphs.original: But in the verity of extolment, I take him to be a soul of great article, and his infusion of such dearth and rareness as, to make true diction of him, his semblable is his mirror. And who else would trace him? His umbrage, nothing more.
paragraphs.translated: Speaking the very truth of high praise, I can honestly say that I find him to possess a soul of such great importance, and so rare and unique in every respect, that - to speak the absolute truth - he can find an equal only when he gazes into a mirror. Anyone else is just a pale copy of him.

paragraphs.original: Your lordship speaks most infallibly of him.
paragraphs.translated: You speak absolutely correctly, sir.

paragraphs.original: The concernancy, sir? Why do we wrap the gentleman in our more rawer breath?
paragraphs.translated: And what's the point, sir? Why are we talking about him like this?

paragraphs.original: Sir?
paragraphs.translated: Sorry, sir?

(speaking so that only HAMLET can hear) Can't you talk to him in a different way?
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: What imports the nomination of this gentleman?
Of Laertes?
paragraphs.translated: Laertes, you mean?

(speaking so that only HAMLET can hear) All his fancy language has run out finally; his pockets are empty.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: Of him, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, Laertes, sir.

paragraphs.original: I know you are not ignorant -
paragraphs.translated: I know you know something -

paragraphs.original: I would you did, sir. Yet in faith, if you did, it would not much approve me. Well, sir?
paragraphs.translated: Thanks for the compliment, I'm happy you know that. But in fact it doesn't say much. I'm sorry, you were saying?

paragraphs.original: You are not ignorant of what excellence Laertes is -
paragraphs.translated: I know you know something about how excellent Laertes is -

paragraphs.original: I dare not confess that lest I should compare with him in excellence, but to know a man well were to know himself.
paragraphs.translated: I can't admit that, since you'd have to compare his excellence to mine. But knowing a person well is a bit like knowing oneself.

paragraphs.original: I mean, sir, for his weapon. But in the imputation laid on him by them, in his meed he's unfellowed.
paragraphs.translated: Excellent in fencing, I mean, sir. His reputation in fencing is unrivaled.

paragraphs.original: What's his weapon?
paragraphs.translated: What kind of weapon does he use?

paragraphs.original: Rapier and dagger.
paragraphs.translated: The rapier and the dagger.

paragraphs.original: That's two of his weapons. But well.
paragraphs.translated: Those are only two of his weapons. But, go on.

paragraphs.original: The king, sir, hath wagered with him six Barbary horses, against the which he has impawned, as I take it, six French rapiers and poniards with their assigns - as girdle, hangers, and so. Three of the carriages, in faith, are very dear to fancy, very responsive to the hilts, most delicate carriages, and of very liberal conceit.
paragraphs.translated: The king has bet six Barbary horses, and he has prepared six French rapiers and daggers with all their accessories. Three of the carriages are very imaginatively designed, and they match the fencing accessories.

paragraphs.original: What call you the carriages?
paragraphs.translated: What do you mean by "carriages"?

(speaking so that only HAMLET can hear) I knew you'd have to look something up in the dictionary before we were finished.
(speaking so that only
can hear)

paragraphs.original: The carriages, sir, are the hangers.
paragraphs.translated: The carriages, sir, are the hangers - where the swords hang.

paragraphs.original: The phrase would be more germane to the matter if we could carry cannon by our sides. I would it might be hangers till then. But, on: six Barbary horses against six French swords, their assigns, and three liberal-conceited carriages - that's the French bet against the Danish. Why is this "impawned," as you call it?
paragraphs.translated: "Carriage" makes it sound like it's pulling around a cannon. I prefer to call it a "hanger." But anyway. Six Barbary horses, six French swords with accessories, and three imaginatively designed carriages - sounds like a French bet against the Danish. Why has all this been put on the table?

paragraphs.original: The king, sir, hath laid that in a dozen passes between yourself and him, he shall not exceed you three hits. He hath laid on twelve for nine, and it would come to immediate trial if your lordship would vouchsafe the answer.
paragraphs.translated: The king, sir, has bet that in a dozen rounds between you and Laertes, he won't beat you by more than three hits. You could get started immediately if you'll give me your answer.

paragraphs.original: How if I answer "No"?
paragraphs.translated: But what if my answer's no?

paragraphs.original: I mean, my lord, the opposition of your person in trial.
paragraphs.translated: I mean, if you'd agree to play against Laertes, sir.

paragraphs.original: Sir, I will walk here in the hall. If it please His Majesty, 'tis the breathing time of day with me. Let the foils be brought, the gentleman willing, and the king hold his purpose. I will win for him an I can. If not, I will gain nothing but my shame and the odd hits.
paragraphs.translated: Sir, I'm going to go for a walk in the hall here whether the king likes it or not. It's my exercise time. Bring in the swords, if the king still wants to go through with it and if Laertes is still willing. I'll have the king win his bet if I can. If not, I'll only have suffered some embarrassment and a few sword hits.

paragraphs.original: Shall I redeliver you e'en so?
paragraphs.translated: Shall I quote you in those exact words, sir?

paragraphs.original: To this effect, sir, after what flourish your nature will.
paragraphs.translated: Just get the point across, however flowery you want to be.

paragraphs.original: I commend my duty to your lordship.
paragraphs.translated: My services are at your command.

paragraphs.original: Yours, yours.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you.

paragraphs.original: Exit OSRIC
paragraphs.translated: OSRIC exits.

paragraphs.original: He does well to commend it himself. There are no tongues else for 's turn.
paragraphs.translated: It's a good thing he's here to recommend himself. No one else would.

paragraphs.original: This lapwing runs away with the shell on his head.
paragraphs.translated: That crazy bird's only half-hatched.

paragraphs.original: He did comply, sir, with his dug before he sucked it. Thus has he - and many more of the same bevy that I know the drossy age dotes on - only got the tune of the time and outward habit of encounter, a kind of yeasty collection, which carries them through and through the most fond and winnowed opinions; and do but blow them to their trial, the bubbles are out.
paragraphs.translated: He used to praise his mother's nipple before he sucked it. He's like so many successful people in these trashy times - he's patched together enough fancy phrases and trendy opinions to carry him along. But blow a little on this bubbly talk, and it'll burst. There's no substance here.

paragraphs.original: Enter a LORD
paragraphs.translated: A LORD enters.

paragraphs.original: My lord, his majesty commended him to you by young Osric, who brings back to him that you attend him in the hall. He sends to know if your pleasure hold to play with Laertes, or that you will take longer time.
paragraphs.translated: My lord, Osric has told the king about your agreeing to the fencing match. The king wishes to know if you want to play against him right away, or wait awhile.

paragraphs.original: I am constant to my purpose. They follow the king's pleasure. If his fitness speaks, mine is ready, now or whensoever, provided I be so able as now.
paragraphs.translated: I'll do whatever the king wants. If he's ready now, so am I. Otherwise, I'll do it anytime, as long as I'm able.

paragraphs.original: The king and queen and all are coming down.
paragraphs.translated: The king and queen are coming down with everyone else.

paragraphs.original: In happy time.
paragraphs.translated: Right on cue.

paragraphs.original:
The queen desires you to use some gentle entertainment to
Laertes before you fall to play.
paragraphs.translated: The queen wants you to chat with Laertes - politely - before you begin your match.

paragraphs.original: Exit LORD
paragraphs.translated: The LORD exits.

paragraphs.original: She well instructs me.
paragraphs.translated: She's full of good advice.

paragraphs.original: You will lose this wager, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: You're going to lose this bet, my lord.

paragraphs.original: I do not think so. Since he went into France, I have been in continual practice. I shall win at the odds. But thou wouldst not think how ill all's here about my heart. But it is no matter.
paragraphs.translated: I don't think so. I've been practicing fencing constantly since he went off to France. With the handicap they've given me, I think I'll win. But I have a sinking feeling anyway. Oh well.

paragraphs.original: Nay, good my lord -
paragraphs.translated: Wait, my lord -

paragraphs.original: It is but foolery, but it is such a kind of gain-giving as would perhaps trouble a woman.
paragraphs.translated: I know I'm being foolish, but I have the kind of vague misgiving women often get.

paragraphs.original: If your mind dislike anything, obey it. I will forestall their repair hither and say you are not fit.
paragraphs.translated: If something is telling you not to play, listen to it. I'll say you're not feeling well.

paragraphs.original: Not a whit. We defy augury. There's a special providence in the fall of a sparrow. If it be now, 'tis not to come. If it be not to come, it will be now. If it be not now, yet it will come - the readiness is all. Since no man of aught he leaves knows, what is 't to leave betimes? Let be.
paragraphs.translated: You'll do no such thing. I thumb my nose at superstitions. God controls everything - even something as trivial as a sparrow's death. Everything will work out as it is destined. If something is supposed to happen now, it will. If it's supposed to happen later, it won't happen now. What's important is to be prepared. Since nobody knows anything about what he leaves behind, then what does it mean to leave early? Let it be.

paragraphs.original: Enter King CLAUDIUS, Queen GERTRUDE, LAERTES, OSRIC, lords, and other attendants with trumpets, drums, foils, a table, and flagons of wine
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS enters with GERTRUDE, LAERTES, OSRIC, lords, and other attendants with trumpets, drums, fencing swords, a table, and pitchers of wine.

paragraphs.original:
Come, Hamlet, come, and take this hand from me. (puts LAERTES' hand into HAMLET's)
(puts
hand into
s)
paragraphs.translated:
Come shake hands with Laertes, Hamlet. (CLAUDIUS places LAERTES' and HAMLET's hands together)
places
and
hands
together

paragraphs.original:
Give me your pardon, sir. I've done you wrong.
But pardon 't, as you are a gentleman.
This presence knows,
And you must needs have heard, how I am punished
With sore distraction. What I have done,
That might your nature, honor, and exception
Roughly awake, I here proclaim was madness.
Was 't Hamlet wronged Laertes? Never Hamlet.
If Hamlet from himself be ta'en away,
And when he's not himself does wrong Laertes,
Then Hamlet does it not. Hamlet denies it.
Who does it, then? His madness. If't be so,
Hamlet is of the faction that is wronged.
His madness is poor Hamlet's enemy.
Sir, in this audience,

Let my disclaiming from a purposed evil
Free me so far in your most generous thoughts
That I have shot mine arrow o'er the house
And hurt my brother.
paragraphs.translated: And if that's true, then Hamlet is the victim of his own illness - his illness is his enemy. Sir, with this audience as witness, let me declare that I'm as innocent of premeditated evil against you as I would be if I had happened to shoot an arrow over my house and accidentally hit my brother.

paragraphs.original:
I am satisfied in nature,
Whose motive in this case should stir me most
To my revenge. But in my terms of honor
I stand aloof, and will no reconcilement
Till by some elder masters, of known honor,
I have a voice and precedent of peace
To keep my name ungored. But till that time
I do receive your offered love like love
And will not wrong it.
paragraphs.translated: My feelings are satisfied - even though what you have done to my father and sister should drive me to revenge. Yet when it comes to my honor, I can't forgive you so fast. I will accept no apology until experts in matters of honor show me how to make peace with you without staining my own reputation in doing so. Until then I will accept your love as love.

paragraphs.original:
I embrace it freely,
And will this brother's wager frankly play. - 
Give us the foils. Come on.
paragraphs.translated: I'm grateful for your love. Come on, give us the swords, and we will play this friendly fencing match enthusiastically.

paragraphs.original: Come, one for me.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, hand me one too.

paragraphs.original:
I'll be your foil, Laertes. In mine ignorance
Your skill shall, like a star i' th' darkest night,
Stick fiery off indeed.
paragraphs.translated: I'm going to make you look sharp, Laertes. I'm so bad at the game that your skill will shine like the brightest star in the darkest night.

paragraphs.original: You mock me, sir.
paragraphs.translated: You're making fun of me.

paragraphs.original: No, by this hand.
paragraphs.translated: No, I swear I'm not.

paragraphs.original:
Give them the foils, young Osric. - Cousin Hamlet,
You know the wager?
paragraphs.translated: Give them the swords, Osric. Hamlet, you know the bet?

paragraphs.original:
Very well, my lord.
Your grace hath laid the odds o' th' weaker side.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord, quite well. You've bet on the weaker fencer.

paragraphs.original:
I do not fear it. I have seen you both.
But since he is better we have therefore odds.
paragraphs.translated: I'm not worried. I've seen both of you fence. But since Laertes is better, we've given him a handicap. He's got to outdo you by three hits to win.

paragraphs.original:
(tests a rapier) This is too heavy. Let me see another.
(tests a rapier)
paragraphs.translated: This sword's too heavy. Show me another one.

paragraphs.original:
(tests a rapier) This likes me well. These foils have all a length?
(tests a rapier)
paragraphs.translated: I like this one. Are they all the same length?

paragraphs.original: Ay, my good lord.
paragraphs.translated: Yes, my lord.

paragraphs.original: HAMLET and LAERTES prepare to play
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and LAERTES get ready to fence.

paragraphs.original:
Set me the stoups of wine upon that table.
If Hamlet give the first or second hit
Or quit in answer of the third exchange,
Let all the battlements their ordnance fire!
The king shall drink to Hamlet's better breath,
And in the cup an union shall he throw
Richer than that which four successive kings
In Denmark's crown have worn. Give me the cups.
And let the kettle to the trumpet speak,
The trumpet to the cannoneer without,
The cannons to the heavens, the heavens to earth,
"Now the king dunks to Hamlet." Come, begin. - 
And you, the judges, bear a wary eye.
paragraphs.translated: Put the goblets of wine on that table. If Hamlet makes the first or second hit, or gets back at Laertes by making the third hit, then let my soldiers give him a military salute. I'll drink to Hamlet's health, and into his goblet I'll drop a pearl even more costly than those in the crowns of the last four Danish kings. Give me the goblets. And now let the drum and the trumpet play, and the trumpet signal the cannon outside to fire, and let the cannon tell the heavens, and the heavens tell all the earth that the king is drinking now to Hamlet's health. Come on, let's begin. Judges, pay close attention.

paragraphs.original: Trumpets
paragraphs.translated: Trumpets play.

paragraphs.original: Come on, sir.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, sir.

paragraphs.original: Come, my lord.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, my lord.

paragraphs.original: HAMLET and LAERTES play
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and LAERTES fence.

paragraphs.original: One.
paragraphs.translated: That was one hit.

paragraphs.original: No.
paragraphs.translated: No, it wasn't.

paragraphs.original: Judgment?
paragraphs.translated: Referee!

paragraphs.original: A hit, a very palpable hit.
paragraphs.translated: It was obviously a hit.

paragraphs.original: Well, again.
paragraphs.translated: Well, let's go on.

paragraphs.original:
Stay, give me drink. - Hamlet, this pearl is thine.
Here's to thy health.
paragraphs.translated: Give me a goblet. - Hamlet, this pearl's yours. Here's to your health.

paragraphs.original: Drums, trumpets sound, shot goes off
paragraphs.translated: Drums and trumpets play, and a gun is fired.

paragraphs.original: CLAUDIUS drops pearl into cup
paragraphs.translated: CLAUDIUS drops a pearl into a cup.

paragraphs.original: Give him the cup.
paragraphs.translated: Give him the goblet.

paragraphs.original:
I'll play this bout first. Set it by a while.
Come.
paragraphs.translated: Let me just finish this round. Set it down awhile. Let's play.

paragraphs.original: HAMLET and LAERTES play
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and LAERTES fence.

paragraphs.original: Another hit. What say you?
paragraphs.translated: Another hit. What do you say?

paragraphs.original: A touch, a touch, I do confess 't.
paragraphs.translated: You got me, I admit it.

paragraphs.original: Our son shall win.
paragraphs.translated: My son will win.

paragraphs.original:
He's fat, and scant of breath. - 
Here, Hamlet, take my napkin, rub thy brows.
The queen carouses to thy fortune, Hamlet.
(picks up the cup with the pearl)
(picks up the cup with the pearl)
paragraphs.translated:
He's flabby and out of breath. - Here, Hamlet, take my handkerchief and wipe your forehead.
The queen drinks to your good luck and happiness, Hamlet. (she lifts the cup with the pearl)
(she lifts the cup with the pearl)

paragraphs.original: Good madam.
paragraphs.translated: Thank you, madam.

paragraphs.original: Gertrude, do not drink.
paragraphs.translated: Gertrude, don't drink that.

paragraphs.original:
I will, my lord. I pray you, pardon me. (drinks)
(drinks)
paragraphs.translated:
Excuse me. I'll drink it if I like. (she drinks)
(she drinks)

paragraphs.original:
(aside) It is the poisoned cup. It is too late.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) That was the poisoned drink. It's too late.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original: I dare not drink yet, madam. By and by.
paragraphs.translated: I'd better not drink now. I'll drink later.

paragraphs.original: Come, let me wipe thy face.
paragraphs.translated: Come on, let me wipe your face.

paragraphs.original: I do not think 't.
paragraphs.translated: I doubt it.

paragraphs.original:
(aside) And yet it is almost 'gainst my conscience.
(aside)
paragraphs.translated:
(to himself) But I almost feel guilty.
(to himself)

paragraphs.original:
Come, for the third, Laertes. You do but dally.
I pray you, pass with your best violence.
I am afeard you make a wanton of me.
paragraphs.translated: Get ready for the third hit, Laertes. You're just playing around. Come on, give me your best shot. I sense you're treating me like a child.

paragraphs.original: Say you so? Come on.
paragraphs.translated: You think so? Come on.

paragraphs.original: HAMLET and LAERTES play
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET and LAERTES fence.

paragraphs.original: Nothing, neither way.
paragraphs.translated: They're neck and neck.

paragraphs.original: Have at you now!
paragraphs.translated: Take this!

paragraphs.original: LAERTES wounds HAMLET In scuffling, they change rapiers. HAMLET wounds LAERTES
paragraphs.translated: LAERTES wounds HAMLET. Then in a scuffle they end up with each other's swords, and HAMLET wounds LAERTES.

paragraphs.original: Part them! They are incensed.
paragraphs.translated: Separate them. They're overdoing it.

paragraphs.original: Nay, come, again.
paragraphs.translated: No, come on, one more time.

paragraphs.original: GERTRUDE falls
paragraphs.translated: GERTRUDE collapses.

paragraphs.original: Look to the queen there, ho!
paragraphs.translated: Take care of the queen!

paragraphs.original: They bleed on both sides. - How is it, my lord?
paragraphs.translated: Both fencers are bleeding - how do you feel, my lord?

paragraphs.original: How is 't, Laertes?
paragraphs.translated: How do you feel, Laertes?

paragraphs.original:
Why, as a woodcock to mine own springe, Osric. I am justly killed with mine own treachery. (falls)
(falls)
paragraphs.translated:
Like a mouse caught in my own trap, Osric. (he collapses) I've been killed by my own evil tricks.
he collapses

paragraphs.original: How does the queen?
paragraphs.translated: How's the queen?

paragraphs.original: She swoons to see them bleed.
paragraphs.translated: She fainted at the sight of them bleeding.

paragraphs.original:
No, no, the drink, the drink! - O my dear Hamlet!
The drink, the drink! I am poisoned. (dies)
(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
No, no, the drink, the drink! Oh, my dear Hamlet! The drink, the drink! I've been poisoned. (she dies)
(she dies)

paragraphs.original: O villainy! Ho, let the door be locked.
paragraphs.translated: Oh, what evil! Lock the door.

paragraphs.original: Exit OSRIC
paragraphs.translated: OSRIC exits

paragraphs.original: Treachery! Seek it out.
paragraphs.translated: We've been betrayed! Find out who did it!

paragraphs.original:
It is here, Hamlet. Hamlet, thou art slain.
No medicine in the world can do thee good.
In thee there is not half an hour of life.
The treacherous instrument is in thy hand,
Unbated and envenomed. The foul practice
Hath turned itself on me. Lo, here I lie,
Never to rise again. Thy mother's poisoned.
I can no more. The king, the king's to blame.
paragraphs.translated: I'm the one, Hamlet. Hamlet, you're dead. No medicine in the world can cure you. You don't have more than half an hour to live. The treacherous weapon is right in your hand, sharp and dipped in poison. The foul plan backfired on me. Here I lie and will never get up again. Your mother's been poisoned. I can't speak anymore. The king, the king's to blame.

paragraphs.original: The point envenomed too! - Then, venom, to thy work.
paragraphs.translated: The blade poisoned! Then get to work, poison!

paragraphs.original: HAMLET hurts CLAUDIUS
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET wounds CLAUDIUS.

paragraphs.original: Treason! Treason!
paragraphs.translated: Treason! Treason!

paragraphs.original: O, yet defend me, friends. I am but hurt.
paragraphs.translated: Protect me, my friends. I've only been hurt, not killed.

paragraphs.original:
Here, thou incestuous, murderous, damnèd Dane,
Drink off this potion. Is thy union here?
Follow my mother.
paragraphs.translated: Here, you goddamn incest-breeding Danish murderer, drink this. Is your little pearl in there? Follow my mother.

paragraphs.original: HAMLET forces CLAUDIUS to drink CLAUDIUS dies
paragraphs.translated: HAMLET forces CLAUDIUS to drink. CLAUDIUS dies.

paragraphs.original:
He is justly served.
It is a poison tempered by himself.
Exchange forgiveness with me, noble Hamlet.
Mine and my father's death come not upon thee,
Nor thine on me. (dies)
(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
He got what he deserved. He mixed that poison himself. Please forgive me as I forgive you, Hamlet. You're not responsible for my death and my father's, and I'm not responsible for yours. (he dies)
(he dies)

paragraphs.original:
Heaven make thee free of it. I follow thee. - 
I am dead, Horatio. - Wretched queen, adieu! - 
You that look pale and tremble at this chance,
That are but mutes or audience to this act,
Had I but time (as this fell sergeant, Death,
Is strict in his arrest), O, I could tell you - 
But let it be. - Horatio, I am dead.
Thou livest. Report me and my cause aright
To the unsatisfied.
paragraphs.translated: God will free you from blame. I'll follow you to heaven in a minute. - I'm dying, Horatio. - Goodbye, miserable queen. - And all you people watching, pale and trembling, speechless spectators of these acts, I could tell you a thing or two if I had the time (though this cruel officer, Death, doesn't allow much free time). Let it be. - Horatio, I'm dying. You're alive. Tell everyone what happened; set the story straight.

paragraphs.original:
Never believe it.
I am more an antique Roman than a Dane.
Here's yet some liquor left.
(lifts the poisoned cup)
(lifts the poisoned cup)
paragraphs.translated:
Not for a second. I'm more like an ancient Roman than a corrupt modern Dane. Some of this liquor's still left in the goblet. (he picks up the poisoned cup to drink)
(he picks up the poisoned cup to drink)

paragraphs.original:
As thou'rt a man,
Give me the cup. Let go! By heaven, I'll have 't.
(takes cup from HORATIO)
(takes cup from
)
O God, Horatio, what a wounded name,
Things standing thus unknown, shall live behind me!
If thou didst ever hold me in thy heart
Absent thee from felicity a while,
And in this harsh world draw thy breath in pain
To tell my story.
paragraphs.translated: Please, give me that goblet, if you love me. Let go of it! I'll get it from you, I swear. Oh God, Horatio, what a damaged reputation I'm leaving behind me, as no one knows the truth. If you ever loved me, then please postpone the sweet relief of death awhile, and stay in this harsh world long enough to tell my story.

paragraphs.original: March afar off and shout within
paragraphs.translated: A military march is heard from offstage, and a cannon fires.

paragraphs.original: What warlike noise is this?
paragraphs.translated: What are these warlike noises?

paragraphs.original: Enter OSRIC
paragraphs.translated: OSRIC enters.

paragraphs.original:
Young Fortinbras, with conquest come from Poland,
To th' ambassadors of England gives
This warlike volley.
paragraphs.translated: Young Fortinbras, returning in triumph from Poland, is firing his guns to greet the English ambassadors.

paragraphs.original:
O, I die, Horatio.
The potent poison quite o'ercrows my spirit.
I cannot live to hear the news from England.
But I do prophesy the election lights
On Fortinbras. He has my dying voice.
So tell him, with th' occurrents, more and less,
Which have solicited. The rest is silence.
O, O, O, O. (dies)
(dies)
paragraphs.translated:
Oh, I'm dying, Horatio! This strong poison's overpowering me. I will not live to hear the news from England. But I bet Fortinbras will win the election to the Danish crown. He's got my vote as I die. So tell him that, given the recent events here - oh, the rest is silence. Oh, oh, oh, oh. (he dies)
(he dies)

paragraphs.original:
Now cracks a noble heart. - Good night, sweet prince,
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest! - 
Why does the drum come hither?
paragraphs.translated: Now a noble heart is breaking. Good night, sweet prince. May hosts of angels sing you to sleep. - Why are those drums approaching?

paragraphs.original: Enter FORTINBRAS and the English AMBASSADOR, with drummer and attendants
paragraphs.translated: FORTINBRAS and the English AMBASSADOR enter with a drummer and attendants.

paragraphs.original: Where is this sight?
paragraphs.translated: What do I see here?

paragraphs.original:
What is it ye would see?
If aught of woe or wonder, cease your search.
paragraphs.translated: What would you like to see? If it's a tragedy, you've come to the right place.

paragraphs.original:
This quarry cries on havoc. O proud death,
What feast is toward in thine eternal cell,
That thou so many princes at a shot
So bloodily hast struck?
paragraphs.translated: These corpses suggest mayhem. Oh, proud Death, what banquet are you preparing that you've needed to knock off so many princes at one stroke?

paragraphs.original:
The sight is dismal,
And our affairs from England come too late.
The ears are senseless that should give us hearing,
To tell him his commandment is fulfilled,
That Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead.
Where should we have our thanks?
paragraphs.translated: This is a horrible sight. Our news arrives from England too late, since the people that should have heard it are dead. We meant to tell the king that his orders have been carried out, and Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead. Who will thank us now?

paragraphs.original:
(indicates CLAUDIUS) Not from his mouth,
(indicates
)
Had it th' ability of life to thank you.
He never gave commandment for their death.
But since so jump upon this bloody question,
You from the Polack wars, and you from England,
Are here arrived, give order that these bodies
High on a stage be placèd to the view,
And let me speak to th' yet-unknowing world
How these things came about. So shall you hear
Of carnal, bloody, and unnatural acts,
Of accidental judgments, casual slaughters,
Of deaths put on by cunning and forced cause,
And, in this upshot, purposes mistook
Fall'n on th' inventors' heads. All this can I
Truly deliver.

Let us haste to hear it,
And call the noblest to the audience.
For me, with sorrow I embrace my fortune.
I have some rights of memory in this kingdom,
Which now to claim my vantage doth invite me.
paragraphs.translated: Let's hear about it right away and invite all the noblemen to listen. As for me, I welcome my good luck with sadness. I have some rights to claim this kingdom, and by arriving at this moment I have an opportunity to put them into effect.

paragraphs.original:
Of that I shall have also cause to speak,
And from his mouth whose voice will draw on more.
But let this same be presently performed,
Even while men's minds are wild, lest more mischance
On plots and errors happen.
paragraphs.translated: I also have a few things to say about that, which Hamlet just told me. But let's get down to business - even though people are in a frenzy of grief - to avoid any further plots and mishaps.

paragraphs.original:
Let four captains
Bear Hamlet like a soldier to the stage,
For he was likely, had he been put on,
To have proved most royally. And, for his passage,
The soldiers' music and the rites of war
Speak loudly for him.
Take up the bodies. Such a sight as this
Becomes the field, but here shows much amiss.
Go, bid the soldiers shoot.
paragraphs.translated: Let four captains carry Hamlet like a soldier onto the stage. He would have been a great king if he had had the chance to prove himself. Military music and military rites will speak for his heroic qualities. Pick up the corpses. A sight like this suits a battlefield, but here at court it shows that much went wrong. Go outside and tell the soldiers to fire their guns in honor of Hamlet.

paragraphs.original: Exeunt marching, carrying the bodies, after the which a peal of ordnance are shot off
paragraphs.translated: They exit marching, carrying the bodies. Cannons are fired.
